text: These are the words that Moses spoke to the assembly of Israel east of the Jordan River, in the Arabah desert, opposite Suph between Paran, Tophel, Laban, Hazeroth, and Di-zahab.
speaker: Narrator

text: It takes eleven days to travel from Horeb to Kadesh-barnea via Mount Seir.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the first day of the eleventh month, in the fortieth year, Moses spoke to the Israelis about everything that the Lord had commanded him concerning them.
speaker: Narrator

text: This took place after he defeated Sihon, king of the Amorites, who lived in Heshbon and Og, king of Bashan, who lived in Ashtaroth at Edrei.
speaker: Narrator

text: East of the Jordan River, in the land of Moab, Moses began to expound this Law:
speaker: Narrator

text: “The Lord our God spoke to us in Horeb. He said, ‘You have been at this mountain long enough.
speaker: Narrator

text: Break camp, get going, and proceed to the hill country of the Amorites and all the nearby places in the Arabah desert, the highlands, the foothills, the Negev, the coastal plains, all of the land of the Canaanites, and Lebanon as far as the great river, the Euphrates.
speaker: Narrator

text: Look! I’ve given you the land that lies ahead. Go in and possess the land that I, the Lord, promised to give to your ancestors Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob, as well as to their descendants.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: “I also told you at that time that I won’t be able to sustain you on my own.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord your God greatly multiplied your numbers, and today you are like the stars in the sky.
speaker: Narrator

text: May the Lord, the God of your ancestors, increase your numbers a thousand times more, and may he bless you, as he promised you.
speaker: Narrator

text: How can I bear the burden of you and your bickering all by myself?
speaker: Narrator

text: Choose for yourselves wise and discerning men, known to your tribes, and appoint them as your leaders.
speaker: Narrator

text: You answered by saying that this plan is a good thing.
speaker: Narrator

text: So I chose leaders from your tribes, wise and respected men, and I appointed them over you—commanders of thousands, hundreds, fifties, and tens.
speaker: Narrator

text: I charged your judges at that time, ‘When you hold a hearing between brothers, judge fairly between a man and his brother or between foreigners.
speaker: Narrator

text: When you hold a hearing, don’t be partial in judgment toward the least important or toward the great. Never fear men, because judgment belongs to God. If the matter is difficult for you, bring it to me for a hearing.’
speaker: Narrator

text: I charged you at that time that you must do all of these things.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Then we set out from Horeb and walked through that vast and dreadful desert, where you observed the road to the Amorite hill country. Just as the Lord our God ordained for us, we finally arrived at Kadesh-barnea.
speaker: Narrator

text: I told you at that time, ‘You have reached the hill country of the Amorites, which the Lord our God is about to give us.
speaker: Narrator

text: Look! The Lord your God has given the land that lies before you. Go and possess it, just as the Lord God of your ancestors commanded you. Don’t be afraid or discouraged.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “Then all of you approached me and said: ‘Let’s send out men in advance of us so they can survey the land and bring back a report to us on how we’ll go up to their cities.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Because this suggestion seemed good to me, I chose twelve men from among you, one from each tribe.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then these men set out, went up to the hill county, reached the Eshcol Valley, and surveyed it.
speaker: Narrator

text: They hand-picked some of the fruit of the land, brought it down to us, and gave a report that said, ‘The land which the Lord is about to give us is good.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: “However, your ancestors didn’t go up. Instead, they rebelled against the command of the Lord your God.
speaker: Narrator

text: You murmured in your tents, ‘The Lord hates us. He brought us out of the land of Egypt in order to deliver us to the Amorites so he could destroy us.
speaker: Narrator

text: Where can we go? Our brothers discouraged us when they said that the people are bigger and taller than we are. Their cities are tall and fortified to the sky, and we also saw the Anakim there.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “Then I told you, ‘Don’t be terrified or afraid of them.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord your God is the One who will be going ahead of you. He’ll fight for you just as he did in Egypt before your eyes.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the desert you saw that the Lord carried you like a man carries his son, on every road you traveled until you reached this place.’
speaker: Narrator

text: But despite this, you didn’t trust in the Lord your God,
speaker: Narrator

text: who walked ahead of you along the way to scout a place for you to pitch camp—by fire at night and cloud by day—to lead you on the way you should go.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “When the Lord heard your complaints, he became angry and declared,
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘I swear that not one man of this evil generation will see the good land that I promised to give to your ancestors,
speaker: Narrator

text: except Jephunneh’s son Caleb. He will see it and I will give to him and to his descendants the land on which he has walked because he wholeheartedly followed the Lord.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “The Lord was also furious with me because of you. He said: ‘You will not enter the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: However, Nun’s son Joshua, your assistant, will go there. Encourage him, for he will cause Israel to take possession of it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Your little ones—whom you said would be taken captive—and your children who do not yet know right from wrong will enter the land. I will give it to them and they themselves will possess it.
speaker: Narrator

text: But as for you, prepare to set out for the desert on the way to the Reed Sea.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “You responded to me and said, ‘We have sinned against the Lord. We will now go up and fight according to what the Lord our God commanded.’ So each man put on his weapon for battle and recklessly started out for the hill country.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Then the Lord told me: ‘Tell them not to go up and fight because I will not be in their midst, or else you will be defeated before your enemies.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “I spoke to you but you didn’t listen. Instead you rebelled against the command of the Lord and went up to the hill country.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Amorites who lived in the hill country came out to engage you in battle. They pursued you like bees do and crushed you from Seir to Hormah.
speaker: Narrator

text: You returned and cried out in the Lord’s presence, but the Lord didn’t hear your voice or listen to you.
speaker: Narrator

text: You remained in Kadesh for many days. It was a long time, indeed.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “We turned and set out for the desert on the road to the Reed Sea, just as the Lord had directed me. We traveled around Mount Seir for many days.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord told me,
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘You’ve walked around this mountain long enough. Turn northward
speaker: Narrator

text: and command this people, “You are about to pass through the territory of your relatives, the descendants of Esau who live around Seir. They will be afraid of you so be very careful.
speaker: Narrator

text: Don’t fight them, because I won’t give you any part of their land, not even the size of a footprint. I have given Mount Seir to Esau as their property.
speaker: Narrator

text: You may buy food to eat and water to drink from them, paying with cash.”’
speaker: Narrator

text: Indeed, the Lord your God blessed all the works of your hands. He knows about your travels through this vast desert. The Lord your God was with you these past 40 years, so that you didn’t lack anything.
speaker: Narrator

text: So we bypassed our relatives, the descendants of Esau who live in Seir. We turned through the Arabah desert from Elath, and from Ezion-geber we traveled the desert road to Moab.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Then the Lord told me, ‘Don’t harass Moab or provoke them to war, because I won’t give you any part of their land. I have given Ar to the descendants of Lot as their property.
speaker: Narrator

text: (The Emites, a people as powerful, numerous, and tall as the Anakim, lived there before.
speaker: Narrator

text: Like the Anakim, they were thought of as Rephaim, but the Moabites called them Emites.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Horites used to live in Seir before the descendants of Esau dispossessed them, exterminated them, and settled there instead, just as Israel will do in the land of its possession, which the Lord gave them.)
speaker: Narrator

text: Now get going and cross the Wadi Zered.’ And so we crossed the Wadi Zered.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now from the time we left Kadesh-barnea until we crossed the Wadi Zered was 38 years. All of that generation, the soldiers in the camp, were destroyed just as the Lord swore they would be.
speaker: Narrator

text: Indeed, the hand of the Lord was against them to root them out from the camp until they were utterly destroyed.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “And so all the soldiers among the people died.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord spoke to me,
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Today, you are about to cross the border of Moab at Ar.
speaker: Narrator

text: When you come to the Ammonites, don’t harass or provoke them to war, for I won’t give any part of Ammonite land to you, since I have given it to the descendants of Lot as their property.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘(Indeed, it was considered Rephaim territory, since the Rephaim used to lived there. The Ammonites called them Zamzummites,
speaker: Narrator

text: a great people, numerous, and tall as the Anakim. But the Lord destroyed the Rephaim, so that the Ammonites dispossessed them and settled there instead.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is what he did for the descendants of Esau who live in Seir, when he destroyed the Horites before them. So they dispossessed them and settled there in their place, where they live to this day.
speaker: Narrator

text: It was the same for the Avvites who lived in villages as far as Gaza. The Caphtorites, who came from Crete, destroyed them and settled there in their place.)
speaker: Narrator

text: Get ready and set out for the Wadi Arnon. Look! I’ve given into your control Sihon the Amorite, king of Heshbon, along with his land. Prepare to take possession by provoking him to war.
speaker: Narrator

text: Starting today I will begin to instill fear and terror of you on the part of every nation under heaven who hears reports about you. They’ll tremble in anguish before you.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: “I sent messengers from the desert of Kedemoth to King Sihon of Heshbon with this message of peace:
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Let me pass through your territory. I’ll stay on the main road. I won’t turn to the right or left.
speaker: Narrator

text: Sell me food for cash, so I can eat and give me water for cash, so I can drink. Just let me pass through on foot,
speaker: Narrator

text: as the descendants of Esau who live in Seir did for me, as did the Moabites who live in Ar. I’ll pass through, until I will have crossed the Jordan into the land that the Lord our God is about to give us.’
speaker: Narrator

text: But King Sihon of Heshbon did not allow us to pass through, because the Lord your God had hardened his spirit and made him arrogant, in order to deliver him into your control today.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Then the Lord told me, ‘See, I’ve begun to deliver Sihon and his territory over to you. Prepare to take possession of his land.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “Sihon came out to meet us, including his entire army, at the battle of Jahaz.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord our God delivered him to us, so we attacked him, his son, and his whole army.
speaker: Narrator

text: We captured all his towns at that time. We utterly destroyed every town—the men, the women, and the children—leaving no survivors.
speaker: Narrator

text: We only appropriated the livestock for our use, along with plunder from the cities that we captured.
speaker: Narrator

text: From Aroer on the edge of Arnon Valley and from the town all the way to Gilead, there was no city that was too strong for us—the Lord our God delivered them all to us.
speaker: Narrator

text: You did not encroach onto Ammonite land, the banks of the Wadi Jabbok, the towns in the hill country, and all the other places that were forbidden by the Lord our God.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “We set out and went up along the road to Bashan. Then King Og of Bashan came out to meet us—he and his whole army—for a battle at Edrei.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord told me, ‘Don’t fear him, because I’ve delivered him, his army, and his territory into your control. Do to him just as you have done to Sihon, king of the Amorites, who lived in Heshbon.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “So the Lord our God also delivered into our control King Og of Bashan, along with his whole army. We attacked him until there were no survivors.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then we captured all his cities at that time. There was not a city left that we didn’t capture from them—60 cities in all from the region of Argob, which is part of the kingdom of Og in Bashan.
speaker: Narrator

text: All of these cities were fortified with high walls, gates, and bars. Furthermore, there were very many unwalled regions.
speaker: Narrator

text: We utterly destroyed them, just as we did King Sihon of Heshbon, attacking them in every city—the men, women, and children.
speaker: Narrator

text: But we kept for ourselves all of the livestock and plunder from the towns.
speaker: Narrator

text: “So at that time, we took control from the two Amorite kings the territory east of the Jordan from Wadi Arnon to Mount Hermon.
speaker: Narrator

text: (The Sidonians called Hermon Sirion, but the Amorites called it Senir.)
speaker: Narrator

text: We took control of all the cities of the plain, all of Gilead and Bashan as far as Salecah and Edrei, cities of the kingdom of Og in Bashan.
speaker: Narrator

text: Only King Og of Bashan remained from the remnants of the Rephaim. In fact, his bed was made of iron. It’s in Rabbah of the Ammonites, isn’t it? It was nine cubits long and four cubits wide.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Of the land that we captured at that time, I’ve given its towns to the descendants of Reuben and the descendants of Gad from Aroer near the Wadi Arnon to half of the hill country of Gilead.
speaker: Narrator

text: The remainder of Gilead and Bashan of the kingdom of Og, I’ve given to the half-tribe of Manasseh. (The whole region of Argob—that is, all of Bashan—is called the land of the Rephaim.)
speaker: Narrator

text: Manasseh’s son Jair captured all the Argob region as far as the territory of the descendants of Geshur and the descendants of Maacath. Bashan was named after him; that’s why it is called Havvoth-jair to this day.
speaker: Narrator

text: Furthermore, I’ve given Gilead to Machir.
speaker: Narrator

text: And I’ve given Gilead to the descendants of Reuben and the descendants of Gad as far as the Arnon Valley, designating the middle of the valley as its boundary, including up to the Jabbok River as a boundary with the Ammonites.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Arabah and the Jordan River are also a boundary from Chinnereth to the Sea of the Arabah (that is, the Salt Sea), below the slopes of Pisgah on the east.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Then I commanded you at that time, ‘The Lord your God gave you this land as a possession. Those equipped for battle—every man a warrior—will cross before your fellow Israelis.
speaker: Narrator

text: However, your women, children, and livestock—and I know you have many—may reside in your towns that I gave you
speaker: Narrator

text: until the Lord grants rest to your fellow Israelis like you. When they take possession of the territory that the Lord your God is about to give them on the other side of the Jordan River, then each of you may return to the territory that I’ve allotted for you.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “I also charged Joshua at that time, ‘You witnessed everything that the Lord your God did to the two kings. Indeed, the Lord will do this to all the kingdoms which you are about to enter.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are not to fear them, because the Lord your God will fight for you.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: “I pleaded with the Lord at that time,
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Lord God, you’ve begun to show your greatness and your strong power to your servant. For what god in heaven or on earth can equal your works and mighty deeds?
speaker: Narrator

text: Let me cross over that I may see the good land on the other side of the Jordan River—the good hill country—as well as Lebanon.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “However, the Lord was furious with me because of you. He did not listen to me. Instead, the Lord said, ‘You are not to speak to me about this matter again!
speaker: Narrator

text: Go up to the top of Pisgah and lift your eyes toward the west, north, south, and east. Look with your own eyes, since you won’t be able to cross this Jordan River.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore charge Joshua to be doubly strong, because he will lead this people and cause them to inherit the land that you’ll see.’
speaker: Narrator

text: We then encamped in the valley opposite Beth-peor.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Now, Israel, listen to the statutes and the ordinances that I’m teaching you to observe so you may live and go in to take possession of the land that the Lord, the God of your ancestors, is about to give you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not add or subtract a thing to what I’m commanding you. Observe the commands of the Lord your God.
speaker: Narrator

text: You saw with your own eyes what he did in Baal Peor. The Lord your God exterminated from among you every man who followed Baal of Peor.
speaker: Narrator

text: But all of you who are clinging to the Lord your God are alive today.
speaker: Narrator

text: See! I taught you the statutes and the ordinances, just as the Lord God commanded. Therefore, observe them when you enter the land you are about to possess.
speaker: Narrator

text: Observe them carefully, because this will show your wisdom and discernment in the eyes of people who’ll listen to all these decrees. Then they’ll say: ‘Surely this great nation is a wise and discerning people.’
speaker: Narrator

text: For what great nation has a god so near like the Lord our God whenever we call on him?
speaker: Narrator

text: And what great nation has all the decrees and righteous ordinances like all this teaching that I’m giving you today?
speaker: Narrator

text: Only guard yourselves carefully so you won’t forget the things that you saw and let them slip from your mind for the rest of your life. Tell them to your children and to your grandchildren.
speaker: Narrator

text: The day you stood in the presence of the Lord your God in Horeb, the Lord told me, ‘Gather the people before me so they may hear my words, learn to revere me the whole time that they live in the land, and teach them to their children.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: “When you approached and stood at the foot of the mountain—a mountain that was blazing with fire at its core while the sky was covered with thick, dark clouds—
speaker: Narrator

text: the Lord your God spoke from the midst of the fire. You heard the sound of words, but you saw no form; there was only a voice.
speaker: Narrator

text: He declared to you his covenant, which he commanded you to observe—the Ten Commandments that he wrote on two stone tablets.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord commanded me at that time to teach you to observe the statutes and ordinances in the land after you cross over to take possession of it.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Therefore, for your own sake, be very careful, since you did not see any form on the day that the Lord your God spoke to you in Horeb from the midst of the fire.
speaker: Narrator

text: Be careful! Otherwise, you will be destroyed when you make carved images for yourself—all sorts of images in the form of man, woman,
speaker: Narrator

text: any animal on earth, any winged bird that flies in the sky,
speaker: Narrator

text: any creeping thing on the ground, or any fish in the sea.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not gaze toward the heavens and observe the sun, the moon, the stars—the entire array of the sky—with the intent to worship and serve what the Lord your God gave every nation.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the Lord took you and brought you out of the iron-smelting furnace—out of Egypt—to be the people of his inheritance, as you are today.
speaker: Narrator

text: “But the Lord was angry with me because of you. So he swore that I’ll never cross the Jordan River to enter the good land that the Lord your God is about to give you as an inheritance.
speaker: Narrator

text: I’m going to die in this land and I won’t cross the Jordan River, but you’re about to cross over to possess that good land.
speaker: Narrator

text: Be careful! Otherwise, you will forget the covenant of the Lord your God, who established that covenant with you. Don’t make carved images of any likeness in violation of everything that you were commanded by the Lord your God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Indeed, the Lord your God is a consuming fire. He is a jealous God.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “After you’ve borne children and grandchildren, have been there for a long time in the land, have become so corrupted that you make images of any form, and have done evil in the eyes of the Lord your God, you will provoke him to anger.
speaker: Narrator

text: Heaven and earth will testify against what has occurred today: you’ll surely and swiftly be destroyed from the land that you are about to possess by crossing the Jordan River. You won’t live long in it, because you’ll certainly be exterminated.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moreover, the Lord will scatter you among the nations, and you’ll be fewer in number in the nations where the Lord your God will drive you.
speaker: Narrator

text: There you’ll serve gods made by human hands, serving trees and stones that cannot see, hear, eat, nor smell.
speaker: Narrator

text: If from there you will seek the Lord your God, then you will find him if you seek him with all your heart and soul.
speaker: Narrator

text: In your distress, when all these things happen to you in days to come and you return to the Lord your God, then you will hear his voice.
speaker: Narrator

text: For God is compassionate. The Lord your God won’t fail you. He won’t destroy you or forget the covenant that he confirmed with your ancestors.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Indeed, ask from one end of the heavens to the other about days of old, before your time, when God created mankind on the earth. Did we ever have anything as great as this, or ever hear of anything like it?
speaker: Narrator

text: Has any people heard the voice of God speaking from the middle of a fire just as you did, and survived it?
speaker: Narrator

text: Or has any god ever taken for himself one nation out from another nation with testings, signs, wonders, wars, awesome power, and magnificent, terrifying deeds as the Lord your God did in Egypt before your eyes?
speaker: Narrator

text: “You have been shown this in order to know that ‘the Lord is God’ and there is no one like him.
speaker: Narrator

text: You have been made to hear his voice from heaven so you may be instructed. And he showed you his great fire here on earth, and you heard his voice from the middle of that fire.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moreover, he loved your ancestors, chose their descendants after them, and brought you out of Egypt, accompanied by his presence and great power,
speaker: Narrator

text: in order to drive out nations that are stronger and more powerful than you, to bring you into this land, and to give you their land as an inheritance, as it is today.
speaker: Narrator

text: “May you acknowledge and take to heart this day that the Lord is God in the heavens above and over the earth below—there is no other God.
speaker: Narrator

text: May you observe his statutes and keep his commands that I’m giving you today, so that life may go well for you and for your descendants after you. That way, you’ll live a long life in the land that the Lord your God is about to give you permanently.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses designated three cities on the east side of the Jordan,
speaker: Narrator

text: where a person who accidentally killed someone could flee, if he killed his neighbor without having enmity toward him in the past. He may flee to one of these cities and live:
speaker: Narrator

text: Bezer in the desert plain for the descendants of Reuben, Ramoth in Gilead for the descendants of Gad, and Golan in Bashan for the descendants of Manasseh.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is the Law that Moses reviewed in the presence of the Israelis.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the instructions, decrees, and ordinances that Moses declared to the Israelis when they came out of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: He did this east of the Jordan, in the valley opposite Beth Peor, in the land of Sihon, king of the Amorites, who lived in Heshbon, and whom Moses and the Israelis defeated after leaving Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: So they took possession of his land, as well as the land of King Og of Bashan. Both Amorite kings lived east of the Jordan—
speaker: Narrator

text: from Aroer on the edge of the Wadi Arnon as far as Mount Sirion, which is also called Hermon,
speaker: Narrator

text: and all the Arabah east of the Jordan as far as the Dead Sea below the slopes of Pisgah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses called all of Israel together and told them: “Listen, Israel! Today I’m going to announce God’s laws and regulations so that you will learn them and take care to obey them.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the Lord our God made a covenant with us in Horeb,
speaker: Narrator

text: it was not with our ancestors that the Lord made this covenant, but with us—we who are here today—all of us who are now living.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke to you face to face on the mountain from the fire.
speaker: Narrator

text: I stood at that time as mediator between the Lord and you to declare his message to you, because you were afraid of the fire and would not go up the mountain. He said:א
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘I am the Lord your God, who brought you out of the land of Egypt—from the house of slavery.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are to have no other gods as a substitute for me.ב
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘You are not to craft for yourselves an idol resembling what is in the skies above, or on earth beneath, or in the water sources under the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are not to bow down to them in worship or serve them, because I, the Lord your God, am a jealous God, visiting the guilt of parents on children, to the third and fourth generation of those who hate me,
speaker: Narrator

text: but showing gracious love to the thousands of those who love me and keep my commandments.ג
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘You are not to misuse the name of the Lord your God, because the Lord will not leave unpunished the one who misuses his name.ד
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘Observe the Sabbath day, maintaining its holiness, just as the Lord your God commanded.
speaker: Narrator

text: Six days you are to labor and do all your work,
speaker: Narrator

text: but the seventh day is a Sabbath to the Lord your God. You are not to do any work—neither you, your son, nor your daughter, your male and female servants, your oxen and donkeys, nor any of your livestock, nor any foreigner who lives among you— so that your male and female servants may rest as you do.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are to remember that you were a slave in the land of Egypt, but the Lord your God brought you out from there with great power and a show of force. Therefore, the Lord your God has commanded you to observe the Sabbath day.ה
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘Honor your father and your mother, just as the Lord your God commanded you, so that you will live long and things will go well for you in the land that the Lord your God is giving you.ו
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘You are not to commit murder.ז
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘You are not to commit adultery.ח
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘You are not to steal.ט
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘You are not to give false testimony against your neighbor.י
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘You are not to desire your neighbor’s wife nor crave your neighbor’s house, his fields, his male and female servants, his ox, his donkey, nor anything else that pertains to your neighbor.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: “The Lord declared these commands in a loud voice to your entire assembly on the mountain from out of the fire and dark clouds, and nothing more was added. He inscribed them on two tablets of stone and gave them to me.
speaker: Narrator

text: When you heard the voice from the darkness while the mountain was blazing, all the leaders and elders of your tribes came to me and said:
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘The Lord our God truly has displayed his glory and power, for we heard him from out of the fire today. We have witnessed how God spoke to human beings, yet they lived.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now therefore, why should we die? This great fire will consume us. If we continue to listen to the voice of the Lord our God any longer, we’ll die.
speaker: Narrator

text: For what mortal man has heard the voice of the living God speaking out of the fire like we did, and lived?
speaker: Narrator

text: As for you, go near and listen to everything that the Lord our God will say to you, then repeat it to us, and we’ll listen and obey.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “The Lord heard what you said. He told me: ‘I’ve heard what this people said. Everything they said was good.
speaker: Narrator

text: If only they would commit to fear me and keep all my commands, then it will go well with them and their children forever.
speaker: Narrator

text: Go and tell them to return to their tents,
speaker: Narrator

text: but you stand here with me and I’ll speak to you all the commands, decrees, and laws that you must teach them to observe in the land that I’m giving you to possess.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must be careful to do what the Lord your God commanded you, turning neither to the left nor to the right.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are to walk in every pathway that the Lord your God commanded you, so that life may go well for you, and so that you will prolong your days in the land that you will possess.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Now these are the commands, decrees, and ordinances that the Lord commanded me to teach you. Obey them in the land you are entering to possess,
speaker: Narrator

text: so that you, your children, and your grandchildren may fear the Lord your God. Keep all his decrees and commandments that I’m giving you every day of your life, so you may live a long time.
speaker: Narrator

text: Listen, Israel! Be careful to obey, so that life may go well for you and that you may increase greatly. Just as the Lord God of your ancestors told you, you’ll have a land flowing with milk and honey.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Listen, Israel! The Lord is our God, the Lord alone.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are to love the Lord your God with all your heart, all your soul, and all your strength.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let these words that I’m commanding you today be always on your heart.
speaker: Narrator

text: Teach them repeatedly to your children. Talk about them while sitting in your house or walking on the road, and as you lie down or get up.
speaker: Narrator

text: Tie them as reminders on your forearm, bind them on your forehead,
speaker: Narrator

text: and write them on the door frames of your house and on your gates.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “When the Lord your God brings you to the land that he promised to your ancestors Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob, he will give you large and beautiful cities that you didn’t build,
speaker: Narrator

text: houses filled with every good thing that you didn’t supply, wells that you didn’t dig, and vineyards and olive groves that you didn’t plant. When you eat and are satisfied,
speaker: Narrator

text: be careful not to forget the Lord your God, who brought you out of the land of Egypt and slavery.
speaker: Narrator

text: Fear the Lord your God, serve him, and make your oaths in his name.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not follow other gods from the gods of the nations around you,
speaker: Narrator

text: because the Lord your God who is among you is a jealous God. He will turn his anger against you and destroy you from the surface of the land.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Don’t test the Lord your God like you did in Massah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Be sure to observe the commands of the Lord your God, his testimonies, and his decrees that he gave you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do what is good and right in the Lord’s sight so it may go well with you. Then you’ll enter and possess the good land that the Lord your God promised to your ancestors,
speaker: Narrator

text: expelling all your enemies before you, as the Lord said.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “When your son asks you in the future, ‘What is the meaning of the instructions, decrees, and ordinances that the Lord our God commanded you?’
speaker: Narrator

text: tell him, ‘We were slaves to Pharaoh in Egypt, but the Lord brought us out of Egypt with great power.
speaker: Narrator

text: Before our very eyes, the Lord did great and terrible signs and wonders in Egypt—to Pharaoh and to his entire household.
speaker: Narrator

text: But as for us, he brought us out from there to bring us into the land and give it to us, as he promised our ancestors.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord commanded us to observe all these decrees and to fear the Lord our God for our own good, so that he may keep us alive as we are today.
speaker: Narrator

text: It will be credited as righteousness for us if we’re careful to obey the entire Law in the presence of the Lord our God, as he commanded.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: “When the Lord your God brings you into the land that you are entering to possess, he will drive out many nations before you: the Hittites, Girgashites, Amorites, Canaanites, Perizzites, Hivites, and Jebusites— seven nations who are more numerous and stronger than you.
speaker: Narrator

text: So when the Lord your God delivers them to you and you have defeated them, then utterly destroy them. You are not to make any covenant with them nor be gracious to them.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are not to intermarry with them. You are not to give your daughters to their sons nor take their daughters for your sons,
speaker: Narrator

text: because they will turn your children from me to serve other gods so that the Lord’s anger blazes against you and swiftly destroys you by fire.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is what you are to do to them: tear down their altars, break their pillars, cut down their ritual pillars, and burn their carved idols in fire,
speaker: Narrator

text: because you are a holy people to the Lord your God. The Lord your God chose you to be his people, his treasured possession from all the nations on the face of the earth.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “It wasn’t because you were more numerous than other nations of the earth that the Lord committed himself to you and chose you. In fact, you were the least numerous of all the nations.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Lord loved you and kept his oath that he made to your ancestors. The Lord brought you out with great power from slavery, from the control of Pharaoh, king of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: Know that the Lord your God is God, the trusted God who faithfully keeps his covenant to the thousandth generation of those who love him and obey his commands.
speaker: Narrator

text: But for the one who hates him, he will repay him by destroying him. He will not delay dealing with someone who hates him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, keep the commands, decrees, and ordinances that I am instructing you to obey today.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “If you pay attention to these laws and obey them, then the Lord your God will continue his covenant of gracious love with you that he promised with an oath to your ancestors.
speaker: Narrator

text: He’ll love you and increase your numbers. He’ll bless the fruit of your womb, the fruit of your land (the grain, new wine, and oil), the offspring of your herds, and the lambs of your flock in the land that the Lord promised your ancestors he would give you.
speaker: Narrator

text: You’ll be blessed among all the nations. There’ll be no infertility among you, not even among your herds.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord will turn aside every disease from you. He won’t inflict on you the terrible diseases you knew in Egypt, but will inflict them instead on all who hate you.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are to utterly destroy everyone whom the Lord your God will deliver to you. Don’t have pity on them nor serve their gods. Otherwise, they will become a snare for you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “You may say to yourselves, ‘These nations are more numerous than we are. How can we dispossess them?’
speaker: Narrator

text: But you mustn’t fear them. Be sure to remember what the Lord your God did to Pharaoh and all of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: Your eyes saw the great trials, the signs and wonders, and the awesome power with which the Lord your God brought you out. The Lord your God will do the same to all the people whom you fear.
speaker: Narrator

text: He’ll send plagues against them until the survivors who hide from you have perished.
speaker: Narrator

text: Don’t tremble before them, because the Lord your God, who is among you, is a great and awesome God.
speaker: Narrator

text: He slowly will dislodge these nations before you, but he won’t destroy them quickly, so the wild animals won’t multiply around you.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Lord your God will deliver them over to you, throwing them into great confusion, until they are destroyed.
speaker: Narrator

text: He will deliver kings into your control and you are to wipe out the memory of them from under heaven. No one will be able to stand before you. You are utterly to destroy them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Burn the images of their gods in the fire. Desire neither the silver nor the gold that adorns them, nor take them for yourselves, so you won’t be ensnared by them, because the gold and silver are detestable to the Lord your God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Don’t bring any detestable thing to your house, because you yourself will be utterly destroyed along with these detestable things. You must absolutely abhor and detest all of it, because it has been devoted to destruction.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Be careful to observe every command that I’m instructing you today, in order that you may live, increase, and enter and take possession of the land that the Lord promised by an oath to your ancestors.
speaker: Narrator

text: Remember how the Lord your God led you all the way these 40 years in the desert to humble and test you in order to make known what was in your heart—whether or not you would keep his commands.
speaker: Narrator

text: He humbled you, causing you to be hungry, yet he fed you with manna that neither you nor your ancestors had known, in order to teach you that human beings are not to live by food alone—instead human beings are to live by every word that proceeds from the mouth of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: “The clothes you wore did not wear out, nor did your feet blister during these 40 years.
speaker: Narrator

text: Be convinced in your heart that as a father disciplines his son, so the Lord your God disciplines you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Observe the commands of the Lord your God by walking in his ways and by fearing him,
speaker: Narrator

text: because the Lord your God is bringing you to a good land—a land with rivers and deep springs flowing to the valleys and hills.
speaker: Narrator

text: It’s a land filled with wheat, barley, vines, fig trees, and pomegranates. It’s a land filled with olive oil and honey—
speaker: Narrator

text: a land without scarcity. You’ll eat food in it and lack nothing. It’s a land where its rocks are iron and you can dig copper from its mountains.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “When you have eaten and are satisfied, bless the Lord your God for the good land that he has given you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Be careful! Otherwise, you will forget the Lord your God by failing to keep his commands, ordinances, and statutes that I’m commanding you this day.
speaker: Narrator

text: Otherwise, when you eat and are satisfied, when you have built beautiful houses and lived in them,
speaker: Narrator

text: when your cattle and oxen have multiplied, and when your silver and gold have increased,
speaker: Narrator

text: then you will become arrogant. You’ll neglect the Lord your God,
speaker: Narrator

text: who brought you out of the land of Egypt—from the house of slavery—and who led you through the vast and dangerous desert—that parched land without water—with its poisonous snakes and scorpions. He brought water out of solid rock for you
speaker: Narrator

text: and fed you in the desert with manna that neither you nor your ancestors had known to humble and test you so that things may go well with you later.
speaker: Narrator

text: You may say to yourselves, ‘I have become wealthy by my own strength and by my own ability.’
speaker: Narrator

text: But remember the Lord your God, because he is the one who gives you the ability to produce wealth, in order to confirm his covenant that he promised by an oath to your ancestors, as is the case today.
speaker: Narrator

text: If you neglect the Lord your God, follow other gods, and serve and worship them, I testify to you today that you will certainly be destroyed.
speaker: Narrator

text: Just like the nations whom the Lord destroyed before you, so will you be destroyed, because you did not listen to the voice of the Lord your God.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Listen, Israel! Today you are about to cross the Jordan to enter and dispossess greater and mightier nations than you, who live in large cities that are fortified to the sky.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Anakim are strong and tall, and you know them. You’ve heard it said, ‘Who can stand up against the Anakim?’
speaker: Narrator

text: But know today that the Lord your God is going ahead of you as a consuming fire. He will destroy and subdue them before you. He will dispossess and destroy them quickly, just as the Lord told you.
speaker: Narrator

text: After the Lord has expelled them before you, you are not to say to yourselves, ‘The Lord caused me to enter and possess this land because of my righteousness.’
speaker: Narrator

text: On the contrary, it is because of the wickedness of these nations that the Lord is dispossessing them before you to confirm what the Lord promised by an oath to your ancestors Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob.
speaker: Narrator

text: Know that it is not because of your righteousness that the Lord your God is giving to you this good land to inherit, since you are a stubborn people.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Remember—and don’t ever forget—how you provoked the Lord your God in the desert. From the day that you came out of the land of Egypt until you came to this place, you have been rebelling against the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: At Horeb you continually rebelled against the Lord so that he was angry enough to destroy you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then I went up to the mountain to receive the two stone Tablets of the Covenant that the Lord had established with you. I stayed on the mountain for 40 days and nights without eating food or drinking water.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord gave me the two stone tablets on which God inscribed with his own finger all the words that the Lord spoke to you on the mountain from the middle of the fire that day when you were all assembled together.
speaker: Narrator

text: At the end of 40 days and nights, the Lord gave to me the two stone Tablets of the Covenant.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Then the Lord told me, ‘Get going! Go down from here at once! Your people whom you brought out of Egypt have become corrupt. They have turned quickly from the way that I commanded them and have cast an idol for their use.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “Then the Lord told me, ‘I have examined this people, and they are stubborn indeed.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let me alone! I will destroy them, blot out their name from heaven, and then I’ll make you into a nation that will be mighty and more numerous than they are.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “So I turned and went down from the mountain while the mountain was on fire. The two Tablets of the Covenant were in both of my hands.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then I saw how you had really sinned against the Lord your God! You had made for yourselves a calf—a cast idol. You had turned aside quickly from the way that the Lord your God had commanded.
speaker: Narrator

text: So I grabbed the two tablets and threw them out of my hands, breaking them before your eyes.
speaker: Narrator

text: I fell down in the Lord’s presence, just as I had the first 40 days and nights. I didn’t eat food or drink water because of your sin. You had sinned by committing this evil in full view of the Lord, thereby provoking him to anger.
speaker: Narrator

text: I feared the anger and wrath of the Lord against you, because he was irate enough to destroy you. But the Lord also listened to me at that time.
speaker: Narrator

text: It was as had been the case with Aaron—the Lord was very angry and about to destroy him, but I prayed for Aaron at that time.
speaker: Narrator

text: So when you made the calf that made you sin, I grabbed it, burned it with fire, crushed it, and ground it thoroughly until it was pulverized to powder. Then I threw the powder into the river that was flowing from the mountain.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “You provoked the Lord again at Taberah, Massah, and Kibroth-hattaavah.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the Lord sent you from Kadesh-barnea and told you, ‘Go possess the land that I gave you,’ instead you disobeyed what the Lord your God said. You didn’t trust him or listen to his voice.
speaker: Narrator

text: You have been rebelling against the Lord since the day I knew you.
speaker: Narrator

text: I fell down in the Lord’s presence for 40 days and nights, because the Lord said he was ready to destroy you.
speaker: Narrator

text: So I prayed to the Lord and said, ‘Oh Lord my God, don’t destroy your people and your inheritance whom you redeemed by your power. You brought them out from Egypt in a powerful way.
speaker: Narrator

text: Remember your servants Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob. Don’t pay attention to the stubbornness, wickedness, and sinfulness of this people.
speaker: Narrator

text: Otherwise, the people of the land from which you brought us will say, “The Lord wasn’t able to bring them into the land that he had promised them. So he brought them out to kill them in the desert because he hated them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But they are your people and inheritance, whom you brought out by your mighty strength and awesome power.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: “At that time, the Lord told me, ‘Chisel two tablets of stone for yourself just like the first ones, and then come up to me on the mountain. Also make for yourself a wooden chest.
speaker: Narrator

text: I’ll write on the tablets what was on the first tablets that you broke, and then you are to place them into the wooden chest.’
speaker: Narrator

text: So I made a chest out of acacia wood and chiseled two tablets of stone just like the first ones. Then I went up the mountain with the two tablets in my hands.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord inscribed on the tablets what he wrote before—that is, the Ten Commandments that the Lord declared to you on the mountain from the middle of the fire during the day of the assembly. And the Lord gave them to me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then I turned, went down the mountain, and placed the tablets in the chest that I had made. They are there now, just as the Lord commanded me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “The Israelis traveled from the wells of the descendants of Jaakan to Moserah. Aaron died and was buried there. His son Eleazar succeeded him as priest.
speaker: Narrator

text: From there they moved on to Gudgodah and from Gudgodah to Jotbathah, a land with flowing streams.
speaker: Narrator

text: At that time the Lord set apart the tribe of Levi to carry the Ark of the Covenant of the Lord, to stand in the Lord’s presence, to serve, and to bless his name until this day.
speaker: Narrator

text: That is why the descendants of Levi do not have a portion and an inheritance among their relatives. As for the Lord, he is their inheritance, just as the Lord your God told them.
speaker: Narrator

text: When I stood on the mountain for 40 days and 40 nights as I did the first time, the Lord listened to me once again. The Lord was not willing to destroy you.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Lord told me, ‘Get up and proceed to lead the people, so they may enter and take possession of the land that I promised to give their ancestors by an oath.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Now Israel, what does the Lord your God desire from you? Only this: fear him, walk in all his ways, love him, serve him with all your heart and in all your life,
speaker: Narrator

text: and observe his commands and statutes that I’m commanding you today for your own good.
speaker: Narrator

text: You see, heaven—even the highest heavens—belongs to the Lord, along with the earth and all that is in it,
speaker: Narrator

text: yet the Lord committed himself to love your ancestors—and did so! He chose you—their descendants after them—from all the nations, as it is today.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, circumcise your heart and stop being stubborn.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the Lord your God is the God of all gods, the Lord of all lords, the great God, mighty and awesome, who does not show favoritism or take bribes.
speaker: Narrator

text: He executes justice for the orphan and the widows, loves the foreigner, and gives them food and clothing.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “You are to love the foreigner, because you were foreigners in the land of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are to fear the Lord your God and serve him. Cling to him and swear by his name.
speaker: Narrator

text: He is the one you are to praise, because he is your God who carried out those great and awesome things for you that you witnessed.
speaker: Narrator

text: Your ancestors went down to Egypt with 70 people, but the Lord your God has now made you as numerous as the stars in the sky.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Therefore love the Lord your God and be very careful to keep his injunctions, statutes, ordinances, and commands all the time.
speaker: Narrator

text: Keep in mind today that I am not speaking to your children, who neither were aware of nor did they witness the discipline of the Lord your God—that is, his great and far-reaching power,
speaker: Narrator

text: including: the signs and works that he did within Egypt to Pharaoh, king of Egypt, and to all his land;
speaker: Narrator

text: what he did to the Egyptian army, to its horses, and to its chariots, when he caused the water of the Reed Sea to engulf them as they pursued you; how the Lord destroyed them, even to this day;
speaker: Narrator

text: what he did for you in the desert until you came to this place;
speaker: Narrator

text: and what he did to Eliab’s sons Dathan and Abiram, descendants of Reuben, when the ground opened up and swallowed them, their households, their tents, and every living thing belonging to them in the full sight of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Your very own eyes saw all the great things that the Lord did.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Keep all the commands that I’m giving you today, so you can be strong enough to enter and possess the land that you are crossing over to inherit
speaker: Narrator

text: and so you’ll live long in the land that the Lord your God promised by an oath to give your ancestors and their descendants—a land flowing with milk and honey,
speaker: Narrator

text: since the land that you are about to enter to inherit isn’t like the land of Egypt that you just left, where you plant a seed and irrigate it with your feet like a vegetable garden.
speaker: Narrator

text: Instead, the land that you are crossing over to inherit is a land of hills and valleys that drinks water supplied by rain from heaven,
speaker: Narrator

text: a land about which the Lord your God is always concerned, because the eyes of the Lord are continuously on it throughout the entire year.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “If you carefully observe the commands that I’m giving you today—that is, to love the Lord your God and serve him with all your heart and soul—
speaker: Narrator

text: then he will send rain on the land in its season (the early and latter rains) and you’ll gather grain, new wine, and oil.
speaker: Narrator

text: He will provide grass in the fields for your livestock, and you’ll eat and be satisfied.
speaker: Narrator

text: Be careful! Otherwise, your hearts will deceive you and you will turn away to serve other gods and worship them.
speaker: Narrator

text: The wrath of God will burn against you so that he will restrain the heavens and it won’t rain. The ground won’t yield its produce and you’ll be swiftly destroyed from the good land that the Lord is about to give you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Take these commands to heart and keep them in mind, tying them as reminders on your arm and as bands on your forehead.
speaker: Narrator

text: Teach them to your children, talking about them while sitting in your house, walking on the road, or when you are about to lie down or get up.
speaker: Narrator

text: Also write them upon the doorposts of your house and gates,
speaker: Narrator

text: so that you and your children may live a long time in the land that the Lord promised to give your ancestors—as long as the sky remains above the earth.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “If you carefully observe all of these commands that I’m giving you to do—to love the Lord your God, to walk in all his ways, and to cling to him—
speaker: Narrator

text: then the Lord will dispossess all these nations before you and you’ll dispossess nations that are even greater and stronger than you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Every place upon which the soles of your feet tread will be yours as boundaries—from the desert to Lebanon and from the River (that is, from the Euphrates) to the Mediterranean Sea.
speaker: Narrator

text: No one will be able to stand against you. The Lord your God will instill terror and fear of you throughout the entire land wherever you go, just as he promised you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Look! I’m about to grant you a blessing and a curse—
speaker: Narrator

text: a blessing if you obey the commands of the Lord your God that I’m giving you today,
speaker: Narrator

text: or a curse if you don’t obey the commands of the Lord your God, by turning from the way that I’m commanding you today and following other gods whom you have not known.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “When the Lord brings you to the land that you are about to enter to inherit, repeat the blessings on Mount Gerizim and the curses on Mount Ebal.
speaker: Narrator

text: They’re across the Jordan River to the west in the land of the Canaanites who live in the Arabah opposite Gilgal near the Oak of Moreh, aren’t they?
speaker: Narrator

text: For you are about to cross the Jordan River to go in and possess the land that the Lord your God is about to give you to inherit and live in.
speaker: Narrator

text: Be careful to obey all the statutes and ordinances that I’m placing before you today.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “These are the statutes and ordinances that you must carefully observe in the land that the Lord God of your ancestors has given you to possess every day that you live on the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Be sure you destroy there all the places where the nations that you’re going to dispossess serve their gods—upon the high mountains and hills and under every leafy tree.
speaker: Narrator

text: Tear down their altars, then cut down their sacred poles and burn them. Cut down the carved images of their gods in order to destroy their names from that place.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “You must not act like this with respect to the Lord your God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Instead, you must seek to enter only the place that the Lord your God will choose among your tribes. There he will establish his name and live.
speaker: Narrator

text: Bring your burnt offerings there, along with your sacrifices, your tithes, your hand-carried gifts, your offerings in fulfillment of promises, your freely-given offerings, and the firstborn of your herds and flocks.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then you and your household will eat in the presence of the Lord your God and rejoice with all the things you have made by your own effort and with which he blessed you.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You must not act as we have been doing here today, where everyone acts as they see fit,
speaker: Narrator

text: since you haven’t arrived yet to your allotted place that the Lord your God is about to give you.
speaker: Narrator

text: But after you have crossed the Jordan River and settled in the land that the Lord your God is giving you to inherit, and after you have received relief from the enemies around you and are living securely,
speaker: Narrator

text: then bring to the place that the Lord your God will choose as a dwelling place—where he will establish his name—everything that I’m commanding you: your burnt offerings, your sacrifices, your tithes, your hand-carried gifts, and all your best offerings in fulfillment of promises that you pledged to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Rejoice in the presence of the Lord your God—you, your sons and daughters, your male and female servants, and the descendant of Levi who is in your city—because there is no territorial allotment for him as you have.
speaker: Narrator

text: Be careful not to offer burnt offerings at any location you happen to see
speaker: Narrator

text: instead of at the place the Lord will choose in one of the tribal areas. There you may offer burnt offerings, and there you may do everything that I’m commanding you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “You may slaughter and eat as much meat as you desire, according to the blessing of the Lord your God, when he provides for you in all your cities. Both ritually unqualified and qualified people may eat it as they would gazelle and deer.
speaker: Narrator

text: However, you are not to consume the blood; instead, you are to pour it out on the ground as you would water.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You won’t be allowed to eat your tithe of grain, new wine, or oil, the firstborn of your herd and flock, your voluntary offerings that you pledged, your free-will offerings, or the works of your hands in your own cities.
speaker: Narrator

text: You’ll eat only in the presence of the Lord your God at the place that he will choose—you, your sons and your daughters, your male and female servants, and the descendant of Levi who is in your cities. Rejoice in the presence of the Lord your God in everything you undertake.
speaker: Narrator

text: Be careful not to forget the descendant of Levi while you live in the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the Lord your God enlarges your territory—just as he told you—and you say ‘I want to eat meat’ since you desire to eat it, you may do so as much as you please.
speaker: Narrator

text: “If the place where the Lord your God chooses to establish his name is distant from you, then you may slaughter from your herd and your flock what the Lord has provided for you, as he instructed you. You may consume them in your cities as much as you please.
speaker: Narrator

text: You may eat them just as you would gazelle and deer. Ritually unqualified and qualified people may eat them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Only be sure to refrain from eating blood, because blood is the source of life and you are not to consume blood with the meat.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are not to eat it; instead, you are to pour it on the ground as you would water.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are not to eat it, so that life may go well for you and for your children after you. Then you’ll do what is right in the eyes of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You may carry and bring only your consecrated gifts and offerings in fulfillment of promises to the place that the Lord will choose.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must offer your burnt offerings—both the meat and the blood—on the altar of the Lord your God. You are to offer the blood by pouring it on the altar of the Lord your God while you consume the meat.
speaker: Narrator

text: Be sure to observe all these words that I’m commanding you, in order that life may go well for you and your children after you forever, for this is good and right in the eyes of the Lord your God.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “When the Lord your God eliminates the nations that you are about to dispossess so you can live in their land,
speaker: Narrator

text: after they have been destroyed in your sight, be careful not to be ensnared as they were. Otherwise, you will seek their gods and ask yourselves, ‘How do these nations serve their gods? I will do likewise.’
speaker: Narrator

text: You must not do the same to the Lord your God, because they practiced in the presence of their gods every sort of abomination that the Lord hates. Moreover, they sacrificed their sons and daughters to their gods.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now as to everything I’m commanding you, you must be careful to observe it. Don’t add to or subtract from it.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “A prophet or a diviner of dreams may arise among you, give you an omen or a miracle
speaker: Narrator

text: that takes place, and then he may tell you, ‘Let’s follow other gods (whom you have not known) and let’s serve them.’ Even though the sign or portent comes to pass,
speaker: Narrator

text: you must not listen to the words of that prophet or that diviner of dreams. For the Lord your God is testing you, to make known whether or not you’ll continue to love the Lord your God with all your heart and soul.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must follow the Lord your God, fear him, observe his commandments, listen to his voice, serve him, and cling to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: That prophet or diviner of dreams must be executed, because he advocated rebellion against the Lord your God, who brought you from the land of Egypt and redeemed you from the house of slavery, and because he lured you from the way in which the Lord your God instructed you to live. Purge the evil from among you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Your own blood brother, your son, your daughter, your beloved wife, or your friend who is like your soul mate may entice you quietly. He may tell you, ‘Let’s go and serve other gods’ (whom neither you nor your ancestors have known
speaker: Narrator

text: from the gods of the people that surround you—whether near or far from you—from one end of the earth to the other).
speaker: Narrator

text: You are not to yield to him, listen to him, look with pity on him, show compassion to him, or even cover up for him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Instead, you are surely to execute him. You must be the first to put him to death with your own hand, and then the hands of the whole community.
speaker: Narrator

text: Stone him to death, because he sought to lure you from the Lord your God, who brought you from the land of Egypt, from the land of slavery.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then all Israel will hear about it, be afraid, and won’t do this evil thing again among you.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You may hear in one of your towns that the Lord your God is giving you to inhabit
speaker: Narrator

text: that worthless men have come from among you to entice those who live in the towns. They may say, ‘Let’s go and serve other gods that you haven’t known.’
speaker: Narrator

text: You must thoroughly investigate and inquire if it is true that this detestable thing exists among you. If it is so,
speaker: Narrator

text: then put the inhabitants of the town to death by the sword. Devote everything in it to divine destruction—even its livestock—by the sword.
speaker: Narrator

text: Gather whatever you’ve taken as spoils at the public square of the town, then burn the town, along with whatever you’ve taken, as an offering to the Lord your God. It will remain a permanent mound of ruins, never to be rebuilt again.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moreover, you must never take any item from those condemned things, so the Lord may yet relent from his burning anger and extend compassion, have mercy, and cause you to increase in number—as he promised by an oath to your ancestors—
speaker: Narrator

text: if you obey the voice of the Lord your God by observing all his commands that I’m commanding you today. Do what is right in the sight of the Lord your God.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “You are children of the Lord your God. You must not lacerate yourselves or shave your foreheads on account of the dead,
speaker: Narrator

text: because you are a holy people to the Lord your God, and the Lord chose to make you his precious possession from among all the nations of the earth.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “You must not eat any detestable food.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the animals that you may eat: ox, sheep, goat,
speaker: Narrator

text: deer, gazelle, roebuck, wild goat, ibex, antelope, and mountain sheep.
speaker: Narrator

text: You may eat every animal with a divided hoof—those with split cloven hooves—that chews the cud.
speaker: Narrator

text: However, you must not eat these animals that chew the cud or have a divided hoof: the camel, hare, and rock badger. Even though they chew the cud, their hooves are not divided. Therefore, they are unclean for you.
speaker: Narrator

text: And also the pig, because even though its hoof is divided, it does not chew the cud. It is therefore unclean for you. You must not eat their meat or even touch their carcasses.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You may choose to eat from these creatures in the water: you may eat anything with fin and scale,
speaker: Narrator

text: but you may not eat anything without fin and scale, since it is unclean to you.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You may eat all clean birds,
speaker: Narrator

text: but you must not eat any of these: the eagle, vulture, osprey,
speaker: Narrator

text: buzzard, any kind of kite,
speaker: Narrator

text: any kind of raven,
speaker: Narrator

text: the ostrich, night hawk, seagull, any kind of falcon,
speaker: Narrator

text: the little owl, great owl, horned owl,
speaker: Narrator

text: pelican, carrion vulture, cormorant,
speaker: Narrator

text: stork, any kind of heron, the hoopoe, and the bat.
speaker: Narrator

text: Any winged, swarming insect is unclean to you—they are not to be eaten.
speaker: Narrator

text: You may eat every bird that is clean.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“You must not eat any carcass, but you may give it to the alien in your cities so he may either consume it or sell it to a foreigner, since you are a people that is holy to the Lord your God.
“You must not cook a young goat in its mother’s milk.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Be sure to tithe annually from everything you plant that yields a harvest in the field.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then in the presence of the Lord your God, in the place where he’ll choose to establish his name, you may consume the tithe of your grain, your new wine, your oil, and the firstborn of your livestock and flock, so that you’ll learn to revere the Lord your God all your life.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the way may be distant from you, so that you are unable to transport your tithe because you have been blessed by the Lord your God and the place where the Lord your God chooses to establish his name may be distant from you.
speaker: Narrator

text: In that case, convert it into cash, secure the money, and then bring it to the place where the Lord will choose.
speaker: Narrator

text: You may spend the money to your heart’s content to buy livestock, flocks, wine, strong drink, and whatever you desire. You and your household may eat there and rejoice in the presence of the Lord your God.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “But you must not forget the descendant of Levi in your town, because there is no tribal allotment for him as there is for you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Every third year, bring all the tithes of your produce of that year and store them in your cities
speaker: Narrator

text: so the descendants of Levi—who have no tribal allotment as you do—foreigners, orphans, and widows who live in your cities may come, eat, and be satisfied. That way, the Lord your God will bless you in everything you do.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “You must cancel your debts at the end of every seventh year.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is the way to conduct remission: every creditor must cancel the loan that his friend borrowed, and he must not pressure his friend or brother to repay it, because remission to the Lord will be proclaimed.
speaker: Narrator

text: You may exact payment from a foreigner, but cancel whatever your brother owes you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moreover, there will be no poor person among you, for the Lord will surely bless you in the land that he is about to give you to possess.
speaker: Narrator

text: Only be certain to obey the voice of the Lord your God. Carefully observe all of these commands that I’m commanding you today,
speaker: Narrator

text: because the Lord your God will bless you just as he promised. You are to lend to many nations, but not to borrow. Also, you will rule over many nations, but they will not rule over you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “If there should be a poor man among your relatives in one of the cities of the land that the Lord your God is about to give you, don’t be hard-hearted or tight-fisted toward your poor relative.
speaker: Narrator

text: Instead, be sure to open your hand to him and lend him enough to lessen his need.
speaker: Narrator

text: Be careful not to think this wicked thought to yourselves: ‘The seventh year, the year of remission, is drawing near…’ and you show ill will toward your poor relative and not give to him. He may then call to the Lord on account of you, and you will be guilty of sin.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must certainly give to him and not feel regret for doing so. Because of this, the Lord your God will bless all your works and everything you do.
speaker: Narrator

text: Since poor people won’t cease to exist in the land, I’m commanding you: Be sure to display generosity to your poor and needy relatives in your land.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “When a fellow Hebrew male or female slave is sold to you and serves you for six years, then in the seventh year you are to set them free.
speaker: Narrator

text: But when you set them free, don’t send them away empty-handed.
speaker: Narrator

text: Provide for them liberally from your flock, threshing floor, and wine vat. As the Lord your God has blessed you, so give to them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Don’t ever forget that you were a slave in the land of Egypt, yet the Lord your God redeemed you. Therefore, I’m giving you these commands today.
speaker: Narrator

text: “If that slave should say to you, ‘I won’t leave you,’ because he loves you and your household, and it was good for him to be with you,
speaker: Narrator

text: then take an awl and pierce through his earlobe into the door. He then will be your slave forever. You are to do the same for your female slaves.
speaker: Narrator

text: Don’t view this as a hardship for yourself when you set him free, for he will have served you for six years—twice the time of a paid worker. Then the Lord will bless you in all that you do.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Set apart for the Lord your God every firstborn male among your herd and flock. You are not to put the firstborn of your ox to work or shear the firstborn of your flock.
speaker: Narrator

text: Instead, in the presence of the Lord your God, you and your household are to eat them every year at the place the Lord will choose.
speaker: Narrator

text: If it has a blemish—lameness, blindness, or any kind of defect—you must not sacrifice it to the Lord your God.
speaker: Narrator

text: In your cities, both the unclean and the clean together are to eat it together, as the gazelle and the deer,
speaker: Narrator

text: but you are not to eat its blood. Pour it on the ground like water.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Observe the month of Abib, keeping the Passover to the Lord your God, because the Lord your God brought you out of Egypt during the night in the month of Abib.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then sacrifice sheep and cattle for the Passover to the Lord your God at the place where the Lord your God will choose to establish his name.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must not eat any yeast with it. Instead, for seven days eat bread without yeast—the bread of affliction—because you left the land of Egypt in haste. Remember the day you went out of the land of Egypt for the rest of your lives.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yeast is not to be seen in any of your territories for seven days. The meat is not to remain from the evening of the first day until morning.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You must not sacrifice the Passover in just any of your cities that the Lord your God is about to give you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Instead, you are to sacrifice the Passover in the evening at dusk—at the time of day you left Egypt—at the place where your God will choose to establish his name.
speaker: Narrator

text: Boil and eat the Passover meal at the place that the Lord your God will choose. In the morning you may go back to your tents.
speaker: Narrator

text: Eat bread without yeast for six days. Then on the seventh day, hold an assembly to the Lord your God. Don’t do any work.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Count off seven weeks from when the sickle is first put to standing grain.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then observe the Festival of Weeks in the presence of the Lord your God by giving your tribute and the freewill offering of your hands in proportion to the manner in which the Lord your God blessed you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Rejoice in the presence of the Lord your God with your son, daughter, male and female slaves, the descendant of Levi who is in your city, the stranger, the orphan, and the widow among you, at the place where the Lord your God will choose to establish his name.
speaker: Narrator

text: Remember that you were slaves in Egypt, so keep and observe these statutes.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Celebrate the Festival of Tents for seven days after you harvest from your threshing floor and your wine press.
speaker: Narrator

text: Rejoice in your festival—you, your son, your daughter, your male and female slaves, the descendants of Levi, and foreigners, orphans, and widows, who live in your cities.
speaker: Narrator

text: For seven days you are to celebrate in the presence of the Lord your God at the place where the Lord will choose, because the Lord your God will bless you in all your harvest and in everything you do, and your joy will be complete.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Every male must appear in the presence of the Lord your God three times a year at the place where he will choose: for the Festival of Unleavened Bread, the Festival of Seven Weeks, and the Festival of Tents. He must not appear in the Lord’s presence empty-handed,
speaker: Narrator

text: but each one must appear with his own gift, proportional to the blessing that the Lord your God has given you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Appoint judges and civil servants according to your tribes in all your cities that the Lord your God is about to give you, so they may judge the people impartially.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must not twist justice, show favoritism, or take bribes, because a bribe blinds the eyes of the wise and subverts the speech of the righteous.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are to pursue justice—and only justice—so you may live and possess the land that the Lord your God is about to give you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “You are not to set up a sacred pole beside the altar of the Lord your God that you will build.
speaker: Narrator

text: Furthermore, you are not to erect for yourselves a sacred stone pillar, because the Lord your God detests these things.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are not to sacrifice to the Lord your God an ox or a sheep that has a defect or any flaw in it, because that is detestable to the Lord your God.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “You may discover that a man or woman living in one of your cities that the Lord your God is about to give you has done evil in the eyes of the Lord your God by transgressing his covenant.
speaker: Narrator

text: He may be following and serving other gods by bowing down to them—that is, to the sun, the moon, or to any of the heavenly host (something I did not command).
speaker: Narrator

text: When it is reported to you or you hear of it, you are to investigate it thoroughly. When the truth has been established that this detestable thing has been done in Israel,
speaker: Narrator

text: summon the man or the woman who did this evil thing to your city gates, and then stone the man or the woman to death.
speaker: Narrator

text: Based on the testimony of two or three witnesses, they must surely die, but they are not to die based on the testimony of one person.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let the witnesses be the first to begin executing them, then the rest of the people are to follow. By doing this you will purge evil from among you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “If a case is too difficult for you to decide with respect to bloodshed, civil claims, assault and battery, or other matters of dispute within your courts, bring it to the place that the Lord your God will choose.
speaker: Narrator

text: Present the case to the Levitical priest or the judge at that time. When you have inquired and they have announced the verdict,
speaker: Narrator

text: carry out the verdict that was declared to you at the place that the Lord will choose. Carefully observe all of their instructions to you
speaker: Narrator

text: in accordance with what the Law says and in accordance with the verdict that will be handed to you. You must not deviate from the verdict that they declare to you either to the right or to the left.
speaker: Narrator

text: If a man presumptuously disregards the priest who is serving the Lord your God there, or the judge, that person must die so you will purge evil from Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then all the people who hear will be afraid and will not act presumptuously again.”
speaker: Narrator
