text: “When you have come to the land that the Lord your God is about to give you, and you have taken possession of it and have settled in it, then you will say, ‘I will appoint a king over me like all the nations around me.’
speaker: Narrator

text: You will certainly set a king over you, whom the Lord your God will choose from among your relatives, but you must not place a foreign king over you who is not from your relatives.
speaker: Narrator

text: He must not amass horses for himself or cause the people to return to Egypt to obtain more horses, because the Lord said you must never return that way again.
speaker: Narrator

text: Also, he must not accumulate wives for himself (otherwise, his affection will become diverted), nor accumulate for himself excessive quantities of silver and gold.
speaker: Narrator

text: When he occupies his royal throne, he must make a copy of this Law for himself from a scroll used by the Levitical priests.
speaker: Narrator

text: It is to remain with him the rest of his life so he may learn to fear the Lord his God and observe all the words of this Law and these statutes, in order to fulfill them.
speaker: Narrator

text: He is not to exalt himself over his relatives, nor turn aside from the commandment—neither to the right nor to the left—so that he and his sons may reign long in Israel.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “The Levitical priests—the whole tribe of Levi—will not have a portion or an inheritance within Israel. Instead, they will eat the burnt offerings of the Lord, because that is their inheritance.
speaker: Narrator

text: But they will not have an inheritance among their relatives, because the Lord alone is their inheritance—as he promised them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “A portion of what the people offer in sacrifice, whether cattle or sheep, is to be due the priests. They must set aside the shoulder, jowls, and stomach for the priest.
speaker: Narrator

text: Give them the first gatherings of your grain, wine, and oil, as well as wool from the shearing of your flock.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the Lord your God has chosen them and their descendants from among your tribes to stand and serve in the name of the Lord all their lives.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Any descendant of Levi who wishes to do so may come from any city or part of Israel where he resides to the place that the Lord will choose.
speaker: Narrator

text: There he may serve in the name of the Lord his God. Like his fellow descendants of Levi who stand there in the Lord’s presence,
speaker: Narrator

text: he may eat the same share as they do regardless of what he receives from his ancestral estate.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “When you enter the land that the Lord your God is about to give you, don’t learn the detestable practices of those nations there.
speaker: Narrator

text: There must never be found among you anyone who sacrifices his son or daughter in fire, practices divination, interprets omens, practices sorcery,
speaker: Narrator

text: casts spells, or who is a medium, an occultist, or a necromancer.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whoever practices these things is detestable to the Lord, and the Lord your God will expel them before you because of these things.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must be completely faithful to the Lord your God,
speaker: Narrator

text: because those nations that you are about to dispossess listen to those who practice witchcraft and divination. But the Lord does not allow you to act this way.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “The Lord your God will raise up a prophet like me for you from among your relatives. You must listen to him,
speaker: Narrator

text: because this is what you asked from the Lord your God at Horeb when you were assembled together: ‘Don’t let us hear the voice of the Lord our God again, or even see this great fire—otherwise, we will die.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “Then the Lord told me: ‘What they have suggested is good.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will raise up a prophet like you from among their relatives, and I will place my words in his mouth so that he may expound everything that I have commanded to them.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if someone will not listen to those words that the prophet speaks in my name, I will hold him accountable.
speaker: Narrator

text: Even then, if the prophet speaks presumptuously in my name, which I didn’t authorize him to speak, or if he speaks in the name of other gods, that prophet must die.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Now you may ask yourselves, ‘How will we be able to discern that the Lord has not spoken?’
speaker: Narrator

text: Whenever a prophet speaks in the name of the Lord and the oracle does not come about or the word is not fulfilled, then the Lord has not spoken it. The prophet will have spoken presumptuously, so you need not fear him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “When the Lord your God destroys those nations whose lands he is about to give you, you must dispossess them and live in their cities and houses.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must reserve three cities within the land that the Lord your God is about to give you to possess.
speaker: Narrator

text: Build roads throughout the land that the Lord your God is providing as an inheritance, and then divide it into three districts so that any killer may flee there.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Now this is the situation for any killer who flees there to live: suppose he strikes his friend unwittingly, not having hated him previously.
speaker: Narrator

text: For instance, he may have accompanied his friend to go to a forest to cut trees. Then he swung his axe to cut some wood, but the ax head flew off the handle and hit his friend, so that he died. The killer may flee to one of these cities to live.
speaker: Narrator

text: Since the distance may be great, the angry avenger may overtake the killer he is pursuing and kill him, in which case there will be no justice in his death, because he did not hate his friend previously.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore I am commanding you to reserve three cities.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Now if the Lord enlarges your territories just as he promised your ancestors and gives you all the land that he promised,
speaker: Narrator

text: and if you are careful to observe all these commands that I am commanding you today—to love the Lord your God and to walk daily in his ways—then add three more cities in addition to these three cities.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must not shed innocent blood on your land that the Lord your God is about to give you as an inheritance. Otherwise, you’ll be guilty of murder.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “However, if a person hates his neighbor, lies in wait for him, rises up against him, and attacks him so that he dies, and then he flees to one of those cities,
speaker: Narrator

text: then the elders of his own city are to send for him, remove him from there, and deliver him to the related avenger for execution.
speaker: Narrator

text: Have no pity on him, but totally purge the shedding of innocent blood from Israel so that life may go well with you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “When you inherit the land that the Lord your God is about to give you, don’t move your neighbor’s boundary marker from where it was placed long ago.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “The testimony of one person alone is not to suffice to convict anyone of any iniquity, sin, or guilt. But the matter will stand on the testimony of two or three witnesses.
speaker: Narrator

text: When a malicious witness takes the stand against a man and accuses him,
speaker: Narrator

text: then both must stand with their dispute in the Lord’s presence, the priests, and the judges at that time.
speaker: Narrator

text: The judges will investigate thoroughly. If the false witness lies in testifying against his relative,
speaker: Narrator

text: do to him just as he intended to do to his relative. By doing this you will purge evil from your midst.
speaker: Narrator

text: When others hear of this, they will be afraid and will not do such an evil deed again in your midst.
speaker: Narrator

text: Your eyes must not show pity—life for life, eye for eye, tooth for tooth, hand for hand, and foot for foot.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “When you go to war against your enemies and observe more horses, chariots, and soldiers than you have, don’t be afraid of them, for the Lord your God who brought you out of the land of Egypt is with you.
speaker: Narrator

text: As you draw near for battle, let the priest approach and speak to the army.
speaker: Narrator

text: He will say to them, ‘Listen, Israel! You’re about to go into battle today against your enemies. Don’t be faint-hearted. Don’t be afraid, don’t panic, and don’t be terrified to face them.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the Lord your God will be with you, fighting on your behalf against your enemies in order to grant you victory.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “Furthermore, let the officials ask the army, ‘Is there a man here who has built a new house but has not yet dedicated it? Let him go back home. Otherwise, he may die in battle and another man dedicate it.
speaker: Narrator

text: And is there a man here who has planted a vineyard and not yet benefited from it? Let him go home. Otherwise, he may die in battle and another man use it.
speaker: Narrator

text: And is there a man here who is engaged to a woman and has not yet married her? Let him go back home. Otherwise, he may die in battle and another man marry her.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “Let the officials also speak to the army, ‘Is there a man here who is afraid and faint-hearted? Let him go back home. Otherwise, he may demoralize his fellow soldier.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “When the officials have finished speaking to the army, they must appoint officers to lead the troops.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “When you approach a city to wage war against it, extend terms of peace.
speaker: Narrator

text: If it agrees to peace and welcomes you, then all the people found in it will serve you as forced laborers.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if they refuse to make peace with you and instead choose war, then attack it.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord your God will deliver it into your control, and you must execute every male.
speaker: Narrator

text: The women, children, all the livestock in the city, and all of the spoil and plunder will belong to you. Appropriate the spoil of your enemies, which the Lord your God will give you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do this to all the cities that are distant from you—that is, to those cities that are not in neighboring nations.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “You are not to leave even one person alive in the cities of these nations that the Lord your God is about to give you as an inheritance.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must completely destroy the Hittites, the Amorites, the Canaanites, the Perizzites, the Hivites, and the Jebusites, just as the Lord your God commanded you,
speaker: Narrator

text: so they won’t teach you to do all the detestable things that they do for their gods. If you do what they teach you, you will sin against the Lord your God.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “When you attack a city and have to fight against it for many days, don’t destroy its trees by cutting them down with an ax. You may eat from them, but you must not cut them down. Are the trees of the field human beings, that you would come and attack them?
speaker: Narrator

text: However, you may cut down the trees whose fruit you know isn’t edible, in order to build siege works against the city that waged war with you, until it falls.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “If a murder victim is found fallen in the open country of the land that the Lord your God is about to give you to possess, and it is not known who killed him,
speaker: Narrator

text: then let your elders and judges go out and measure the distance from the dead body to the neighboring cities.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the elders of the city nearest the body are to take a heifer that hasn’t been put to work or hasn’t pulled a yoke
speaker: Narrator

text: and are to lead the heifer to a flowing stream in a valley that has never been tilled or planted. They are to break the heifer’s neck there.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the priests of the descendants of Levi are to step forward, because the Lord your God chose them to serve and pronounce blessings in his name. Every case of dispute and assault is to be subject to their ruling.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the elders of the city nearest the dead body are to wash their hands over the heifer whose neck was broken in the valley,
speaker: Narrator

text: and they are to make this declaration: ‘Our hands didn’t shed this blood, nor were we witnesses to the crime.
speaker: Narrator

text: Make atonement for your people Israel, whom you have redeemed, Lord, and don’t charge the blood of an innocent man against them.’ Then the blood that has been shed will be atoned for.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is how you will remove the guilt of innocent blood from among you, for you must do what is right in the sight of the Lord.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “If you go to battle against your enemies, and the Lord your God delivers them into your control, you may take some prisoners captive.
speaker: Narrator

text: If you see among the prisoners a beautiful woman and you desire her, then you may take her as your wife.
speaker: Narrator

text: Bring her to your house, but shave her head and trim her nails.
speaker: Narrator

text: Remove her prisoner’s clothing and let her remain for a month in your house, mourning her parents. After that, you may become her husband and she is to become your wife.
speaker: Narrator

text: If you aren’t pleased with her and you send her away, you must not sell her for money or mistreat her, since you will have dishonored her.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “If a man has two wives where one is loved but the other is unloved, and both of them bear him sons, but the firstborn is the son of the unloved wife,
speaker: Narrator

text: then when he bequeaths his possessions to his sons, he must not give preference to the firstborn of the beloved wife over the firstborn of the unloved wife.
speaker: Narrator

text: Instead, he must acknowledge the firstborn of the unloved wife by giving him double of everything he owns, because he is really the first fruit of his father’s strength. The right of the firstborn belongs to him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “If a man has a stubborn son who does not obey his parents, and although they try to discipline him, he still refuses to pay attention to them,
speaker: Narrator

text: then his parents are to seize him and bring him before the elders at the gate of his city.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they are to declare to the elders of their city: ‘Our son is stubborn and rebellious. He does not obey us. He lives wildly and is a drunkard.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Then all the men of his city are to stone him with boulders so that he dies. This is how you will remove this evil from among you. Then all Israel will hear of it and will be afraid.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “If a man is guilty of a capital offense, is executed, and then is impaled on a tree,
speaker: Narrator

text: his body must not remain overnight on the tree. You must bury him that same day, because cursed of God is the one who has been hanged on a tree. Don’t defile your land that the Lord is about to give you as your inheritance.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “When you see the ox or sheep of your fellow countryman straying, don’t go away and leave it. Instead, be sure to return it to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: If your fellow countryman doesn’t live near you or you don’t know who he is, bring the animal to your house and let it remain with you until he claims it. Then return it to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do the same for his donkey, his garment, and for anything lost that belongs to your fellow countryman. When you find it, you must not ignore it.
speaker: Narrator

text: When you see the donkey or the ox of your fellow countryman fallen on the road, don’t ignore it. Instead be sure to help it get up.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “A woman is not to wear what is appropriate to a man, nor is a man to put on a woman’s garment, because anyone who does this is detestable to the Lord your God.
speaker: Narrator

text: “When you encounter a bird’s nest along the road, whether in a tree or on the ground, and the mother bird is sitting on its chicks or eggs, don’t take the mother along with its young.
speaker: Narrator

text: You may take the young, but be sure to release the mother, so that life will go well for you and that you may have a long life.
speaker: Narrator

text: “When you build a new house, install a parapet along your roof so that if someone falls from the roof, you won’t bring guilt of bloodshed on your house.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Don’t plant two kinds of seeds in your vineyard. Otherwise, the entire crop will have to be forfeited, both the seed that you have sown and the produce from it.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Don’t plow with an ox and a donkey yoked together.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Don’t wear material made from wool and linen mixed together.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Sew tassels for yourself on the four corners of the garment with which you cover yourself.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Suppose a man marries a wife, but after having sexual relations with her, he despises her,
speaker: Narrator

text: invents charges against her, and defames her by saying, ‘I have married this woman, but when I had sexual relations with her I found that she wasn’t a virgin.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the father of the young lady, along with her mother, is to bring evidence of the young lady’s virginity to the elders at the gate.
speaker: Narrator

text: The father of the young lady is to then say to the elders: ‘I have given my daughter to this man as a wife, but he despises her.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now look, he has invented charges against her by saying, “I haven’t found your daughter to be a virgin.” But here is the proof of my daughter’s virginity.’ Then they are to spread the cloth before the elders of the city.
speaker: Narrator

text: The elders of that city will then take the man, punish him,
speaker: Narrator

text: fine him 100 shekels of silver, and then give them to the young lady’s father, because he defamed a virgin of Israel. She is to remain his wife and he can’t divorce her as long as he lives.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if this charge is true, and the evidence of the young lady’s virginity wasn’t found,
speaker: Narrator

text: they are to bring her to the door of her father’s house. Then the men of the city are to stone her with boulders until she dies for doing a detestable thing in Israel—acting like a prostitute while in her father’s house. By doing this, you will remove this evil from among you.
speaker: Narrator

text: “If a man is caught having sexual relations with a married woman, then both of them must die—the man who had sex with the woman and the woman herself—so that this evil will be removed from Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: “If a man meets a young virgin lady in the city who is engaged to be married and has sexual relations with her,
speaker: Narrator

text: then the two must be brought to the city gate and there they must be stoned to death—the girl because she was in a city but did not cry out for help, and the man who abused a woman who was engaged to another man. By doing this you are to remove this evil from among you.
speaker: Narrator

text: “If a man meets a girl in the country who is engaged to be married and then rapes her, the man alone—the one who had sexual relations with her—must die.
speaker: Narrator

text: As for the young lady, don’t do anything to her. The young lady did nothing worthy of death. This case is similar to when a man attacks his countryman and kills him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Since he found her in the country, the engaged girl may have cried out, but there was no one to rescue her.
speaker: Narrator

text: “However, if a man meets a girl who isn’t engaged to be married, and he seizes her, rapes her, and is later found out,
speaker: Narrator

text: then the man who raped her must give 50 shekels of silver to the girl’s father. Furthermore, he must marry her. Because he violated her, he is to not divorce her as long as he lives.
speaker: Narrator

text: “A man must not marry his father’s wife, so that he will not dishonor his father’s memory.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “No man whose testicles have been crushed or whose penis has been cut off may participate in the assembly of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Furthermore, no one born due to an illicit sexual relationship may participate in the assembly of the Lord, including his descendants to the tenth generation.
speaker: Narrator

text: No Ammonite or Moabite may participate in the assembly of the Lord, and none of their descendants is to be admitted to the assembly of the Lord, to the tenth generation,
speaker: Narrator

text: because they didn’t come to meet you with food and water along the way as you were coming out of Egypt. Instead, they hired Beor’s son Balaam from Pethor in Aram-naharaim to curse you.
speaker: Narrator

text: However, the Lord your God didn’t listen to Balaam. The Lord your God turned Balaam’s curse into a blessing, because the Lord your God loves you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Don’t seek a peace treaty with them as long as you live.
speaker: Narrator

text: Don’t detest Edomites, since they are related to you. Don’t detest Egyptians, either, because you were strangers in their land.
speaker: Narrator

text: Their grandchildren may participate in the assembly of the Lord.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “When you are encamped for battle against your enemies, be on guard against every form of impropriety.
speaker: Narrator

text: If someone among you becomes unclean due to nocturnal emissions, he must leave the camp and stay outside.
speaker: Narrator

text: As evening approaches, he must wash himself with water. Then at sunset, he may return to the camp.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Choose a place outside the camp for a latrine.
speaker: Narrator

text: Include a spade among your equipment so that when you squat to relieve yourself, you can dig a hole and then cover your excrement.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the Lord your God is on the move within your camp to deliver you and to hand your enemies over to you. Therefore, your camp must be holy so that he will not see anything indecent among you and turn away from you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Don’t hand over a slave who escaped from his master when he runs to you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let him live among you wherever he chooses in any of your cities that he likes. Don’t mistreat him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “There are to be no cultic prostitutes among the daughters or the sons of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Don’t bring the earnings of a female prostitute nor the income of a male prostitute into the house of the Lord your God as payment for any vow. Both of these are detestable to the Lord your God.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Don’t charge interest to your relatives, whether for money, food, or for anything that has been loaned at interest.
speaker: Narrator

text: You may charge interest to a foreigner, but don’t charge interest to your relatives, so the Lord your God may bless you in everything you undertake in the land that you are about to enter and possess.
speaker: Narrator

text: “When you make a vow to the Lord your God, don’t delay paying it, because the Lord your God will certainly demand payment from you, and then you will be guilty of sin.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if you refrain from making a vow, then you won’t be guilty.
speaker: Narrator

text: Be sure you do whatever you promise, because you have given your word voluntarily to the Lord your God.
speaker: Narrator

text: “When you enter your countrymen’s vineyard, you may eat the grapes to your satisfaction, but don’t take any in a basket.
speaker: Narrator

text: When you enter your countrymen’s grain fields, you may pluck the grain with your hand, but don’t put a sickle to his standing grain.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “If a man chooses to enter into marriage with a woman, but she finds herself displeasing to him because he has found something objectionable about her, he must draw up divorce papers, hand them to her, and then send her out of his house.
speaker: Narrator

text: If she goes out from his house, becomes the wife of another man,
speaker: Narrator

text: and this second husband dislikes her, he, also, must draw up divorce papers, hand them to her, and then send her away from his house. Should the second husband die,
speaker: Narrator

text: her first husband who married her and divorced her earlier must not remarry her, because she was defiled, since this is detestable to the Lord. Don’t defile the land that the Lord your God is about to give you as a possession.
speaker: Narrator

text: “When a man is newly married, he must not be sent out to war or have a related duty placed on him. Let him stay home for one year and be happy with his wife whom he has married.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Don’t take a pair of millstones, especially the upper millstone, as collateral for a loan, because this means taking a man’s livelihood.
speaker: Narrator

text: “If a man is found kidnapping his relative, a fellow Israeli, and mistreats or sells him, that kidnapper must die. By doing this, you will remove this evil from among you.
speaker: Narrator

text: “In cases of leprosy, be very careful to observe exactly what the Levitical priests instructed you. Carefully follow what I have commanded them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Remember what the Lord your God did to Miriam along the way as you were coming out of Egypt.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “When you loan something to your neighbor, don’t enter his house to seize what he offered as collateral.
speaker: Narrator

text: Stay outside and let the man to whom you made the loan bring it out to you.
speaker: Narrator

text: If he is a poor man, don’t go to sleep with his collateral in your possession.
speaker: Narrator

text: Be sure to return his garment to him at sunset so that he may sleep with it, and he will bless you. It will be a righteous deed in the presence of the Lord your God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Don’t take advantage of a hired person who is poor and needy, whether he’s your fellow citizen or a foreigner who lives in your city.
speaker: Narrator

text: Pay his wages that same day before the sun sets, because he is poor and his livelihood depends on it. Otherwise, he may cry out to the Lord against you, and you will incur guilt.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Fathers are not to be put to death on account of their children’s sin; nor are children to die on account of their fathers’ sin. Each person is to be put to death for his own sin.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Don’t deny justice to a foreigner or to an orphan, nor take a widow’s garment as collateral for a loan.
speaker: Narrator

text: Remember to observe this because you were slaves in Egypt, and the Lord your God redeemed you from there. That is why I am commanding you to do this.
speaker: Narrator

text: “When you are reaping in the field, and you overlook a sheaf, don’t return to get it. Let it remain for the foreigner, the orphan, or the widow, in order that the Lord your God may bless everything you undertake.
speaker: Narrator

text: When you harvest the olives from your trees, don’t go back to the branches a second time. What remains is for the foreigner, the orphan, or the widow.
speaker: Narrator

text: When you harvest the grapes in your vineyard, don’t go back a second time. What remains is for the foreigner, the orphan, or the widow.
speaker: Narrator

text: Remember to do this because you were slaves in the land of Egypt. That is why I’m commanding you to do this.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “When there is a conflict between individuals, let them come to court to judge the case, decide who is innocent, and condemn the guilty person.
speaker: Narrator

text: If the guilty person deserves a beating, the judge will make him lie down and be beaten in his presence with the number of lashes fit for his crime.
speaker: Narrator

text: But he must not be beaten more than 40 lashes, because if he receives more than 40 lashes, your brother will be humiliated in your eyes.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Don’t muzzle an ox while it is threshing grain.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “When two brothers are living together and one of them dies without leaving a son, his widow must not be married outside the family to a foreigner. Instead, the brother-in-law must go to her, take her as his wife, and by doing so perform the duty of a brother-in-law.
speaker: Narrator

text: The firstborn whom she will bear will continue the name of the dead brother, so his name will not be erased from Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if the man does not want to marry his brother’s widow, then she must go to the elders at the city gate and declare, ‘My husband’s brother refuses to perform the duty of a brother-in-law in order to preserve the name of his brother in Israel. He is not willing to perform the duty of a brother-in-law.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the elders of the city are to summon him and speak with him. If he insists on saying, ‘I don’t want to marry her,’
speaker: Narrator

text: then she is to approach her brother-in-law in the presence of the elders, remove his sandal, spit in his face, and say in response, ‘May this be done to the man who does not preserve the lineage of his brother.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Then his family name in Israel will be known as ‘the family of the one whose sandal was removed.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: “If two men are fighting together, and the wife of one comes to rescue her husband from the grasp of his assailant, and she reaches out and seizes his genitals,
speaker: Narrator

text: you are to cut off her hand. Don’t show any pity.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Don’t have different weights in your bag—one heavy and one light.
speaker: Narrator

text: Don’t have different measuring devices in your house—one large and one small.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must have honest weights and measuring devices, so you may live long in the land that the Lord your God is about to give you,
speaker: Narrator

text: for anyone who does these things—anyone who deals dishonestly—is detestable to the Lord your God.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Remember what the Amalekites did to you along the road while you were coming out of Egypt,
speaker: Narrator

text: how when you were very tired and weary, they lay in wait for you on the road and eliminated everyone who was lagging behind. They had no fear of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, when the Lord your God has given you rest from all your enemies who surround you in the land that he is about to give you to possess as an inheritance, you must completely erase the memory of the Amalekites from under heaven. Don’t forget!”
speaker: Narrator

text: “When you arrive in the land that the Lord your God is about to give you as an inheritance, take possession of it and settle in it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Gather all the first produce of the ground that you harvest from your land that the Lord your God is about to give you, place it in a basket, and bring it to the place where the Lord your God will choose to establish his name.
speaker: Narrator

text: Approach the priest who is in charge at that time and say to him, ‘I acknowledge today to the Lord your God that I’ve arrived in the land that the Lord promised our ancestors to give us.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the priest will take the basket from you and place it in front of the altar of the Lord your God.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then you are to affirm and declare in the presence of the Lord your God:
‘A wandering Aramean was my ancestor, who went down to Egypt and traveled there with very few family members, yet there he became a great, powerful, and populous nation.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Egyptians oppressed us, afflicted us, and assigned us to hard labor.
speaker: Narrator

text: So we cried out to the Lord God of our ancestors, and he heard our cries and observed our affliction, trouble, and oppression.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord brought us out of Egypt with his awesome power, with great terror, signs, and wonders.
speaker: Narrator

text: And then we arrived at this place, and he gave this land to us, flowing with milk and honey.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Now, look—I brought the first produce of the land that you, Lord, have given me.’
Then set it in the presence of the Lord your God and worship him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Rejoice with the descendants of Levi and the foreigner among you at all the good things that the Lord your God has given you and your family.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “When you have finished your harvest, reserve the tithe in the third year (the year of the tithe), and give the entire tithe to the descendants of Levi, to the foreigners, to the orphans, and to the widows, so they may eat and be satisfied in your cities.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then declare in the presence of the Lord your God:
‘I’ve removed the holy offering from my house and given it to the descendants of Levi, to the foreigners, to the orphans, and to the widows just as you have commanded me. I haven’t violated or forgotten your commands.
speaker: Narrator

text: I haven’t eaten any part of it while mourning, nor removed any part of it while unclean, nor offered any of it to the dead. I’ve obeyed the voice of the Lord my God and did all that he commanded me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Look down from your holy habitation in heaven and bless your people Israel and the land that you have given us, just as you promised our ancestors—a land flowing with milk and honey.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: “The Lord your God is commanding you this very day to observe these statutes and judgments. Be careful to obey them with all your heart and soul.
speaker: Narrator

text: You have declared this very day that the Lord will be your God. You are to walk in his ways, keep his statutes, commands, and judgments, and obey his voice.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord affirmed this day that you are his prized possession. Therefore, observe his commands,
speaker: Narrator

text: so he may elevate you far above all the nations that he has made. Then you will live to the praise, fame, and glory of God, and so be a nation that is holy to the Lord your God, as he has promised.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses and the elders of Israel gave these orders to the people: “Observe all of the commandments that I’m giving you today.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the day you cross over the Jordan River to the land that the Lord your God is about to give you, set up large stones and coat them with plaster.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then inscribe on them all the words of this Law when you’ve crossed over into the land that the Lord your God is about to give you—a land flowing with milk and honey—just as the Lord God of your ancestors promised you.
speaker: Narrator

text: “When you have crossed the Jordan River, set up these stones about which I’m commanding you today on Mount Ebal, and coat them with plaster.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then build an altar there to the Lord your God, an altar of stones that hasn’t been worked with iron tools.
speaker: Narrator

text: Build the altar to the Lord your God with uncut stones, then offer a burnt offering to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Offer a burnt offering there, then eat and rejoice in the presence of the Lord your God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Inscribe on the stones plainly and distinctly all the words of this Law.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses and the Levitical priests spoke to Israel. They said, “Be quiet and listen, Israel! Today you have become the people of the Lord your God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Listen to his voice and carry out his commands and statutes that I’m giving you today.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses gave the people these commands that day:
speaker: Narrator

text: “When you cross the Jordan River, these tribes are to stand on Mount Gerizim to bless the people—Simeon, Levi, Judah, Issachar, Joseph, and Benjamin.
speaker: Narrator

text: The tribes of Reuben, Gad, Asher, Zebulun, Dan, and Naphtali are to stand on Mount Ebal to pronounce the curse.
speaker: Narrator

text: The descendants of Levi are to declare in a loud voice to every Israeli:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“‘Cursed is the one who makes a sculptured or cast image—a detestable thing to the Lord, the work of a craftsman—and sets it up secretly.’
“Then all the people are to respond by saying, ‘Amen!’
speaker: Narrator

text:
“‘Cursed is the one who treats his father and mother with dishonor.’
“Then all the people are to respond by saying, ‘Amen!’
speaker: Narrator

text:
“‘Cursed is the one who moves his neighbor’s boundary stone.’
“Then all the people are to respond by saying, ‘Amen!’
speaker: Narrator

text:
“‘Cursed is the one who misleads a blind person on the road.’
“Then all the people are to respond by saying, ‘Amen!’
speaker: Narrator

text:
“‘Cursed is the one who perverts justice due the foreigner, the orphan, or the widow.’
“Then all the people are to respond by saying, ‘Amen!’
speaker: Narrator

text:
“‘Cursed is the one who has sexual relations with his father’s wife, because he has disgraced his father.’
“Then all the people are to respond by saying, ‘Amen!’
speaker: Narrator

text:
“‘Cursed is the one who has sexual relations with any animal.’
“Then all the people are to respond by saying, ‘Amen!’
speaker: Narrator

text:
“‘Cursed is the one who has sexual relations with his sister, the daughter of his father or mother.’
“Then all the people are to respond by saying, ‘Amen!’
speaker: Narrator

text:
“‘Cursed is the one who has sexual relations with his mother-in-law.’
“Then all the people are to respond by saying, ‘Amen!’
speaker: Narrator

text:
“‘Cursed is one who strikes his neighbor secretly.’
“Then all the people are to respond by saying, ‘Amen!’
speaker: Narrator

text:
“‘Cursed is one who accepts a bribe to kill an innocent person.’
“Then all the people are to respond by saying, ‘Amen!’
speaker: Narrator

text:
“‘Cursed is the one who doesn’t uphold the words of this Law and observe them.’
“Then all the people are to respond by saying, ‘Amen!’”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Indeed, if you diligently obey the Lord your God to carry out all his commands that I’m giving you today, then the Lord your God will set you high above all the nations of the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moreover, all these blessings will come upon you in abundance, if you obey the Lord your God:
speaker: Narrator

text: “Blessed will you be in the city and blessed will you be in the country.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Blessed will your children be, as well as the produce of your land, the offspring of your beasts and cattle, and the offspring of your flock.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Blessed will be your grain basket and your kneading bowl.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Blessed will you be in your comings and goings.
speaker: Narrator

text: “The Lord will make your enemies, who rise against you and attack from one direction, to flee from you in seven directions.
speaker: Narrator

text: “The Lord will send blessings for you with regard to your barns and everything you undertake. Indeed, he will bless you in the land that the Lord your God is about to give you.
speaker: Narrator

text: “The Lord will assign you to be a holy people for himself, just as he promised you, as long as you keep his commands and walk in his ways.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Then all the people of the earth will observe that the name of the Lord is proclaimed among you, and they will fear you.
speaker: Narrator

text: “The Lord will show his abundant goodness with respect to your children, the offspring of your animals, and the produce of your farmland that he promised your ancestors he would give you.
speaker: Narrator

text: “The Lord will open his rich treasury, the heavens, to release rain upon your land in season and bless everything you undertake so that you’ll lend to many nations but won’t borrow.
speaker: Narrator

text: “The Lord your God will make you the head and not the tail—placing you above and not beneath—if you obey the commands of the Lord your God that I’m giving you today to keep and observe.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not deviate from any of his commands that I’m giving you today—neither to the right nor the left—to follow and serve other gods.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “But if you don’t obey the Lord your God and faithfully carry out all his commands and statutes that I’m giving you today, then all these curses will come upon you and overwhelm you:
speaker: Narrator

text: “Cursed will you be in the city and cursed will you be in the country.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Cursed will be your grain basket and your kneading bowl.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Cursed will your children be, as well as the produce of your land, the offspring of your beasts and cattle, and the offspring of your flock.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Cursed will you be in your comings and goings.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “The Lord will send the curse among you, will confuse you, and will rebuke you in everything you undertake until you are destroyed and perish quickly because of your evil deeds, since you will have forsaken him.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord will cause you to be ill with long-lasting diseases until you are wiped out from the land that you are entering to possess.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord will afflict you with tuberculosis, fever, inflammation, high fever, drought, blight, and mildew. These will attack you until you are completely destroyed.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sky above your head will become bronze while the ground beneath you will become iron.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord will change the rain on your land to powder and dust. It will come down from the sky until you are exterminated.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “The Lord will cause you to be defeated by your enemies. You’ll go out against them in one direction, but you’ll flee from them in seven directions. Consequently, you’ll be in a state of great terror throughout all the kingdoms of the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Your dead bodies will be food for the birds of the sky and the wild animals of the earth, with no one to chase them away.
speaker: Narrator

text: “The Lord will afflict you with the boils of Egypt, with tumors, skin disease, and festering rashes, and none of them will be curable.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord will afflict you with insanity, blindness, and mental confusion.
speaker: Narrator

text: As a result, you’ll wander aimlessly in broad daylight just as a blind person wanders in darkness. You won’t prosper in life. Instead, you’ll be oppressed and plundered all day long, with no deliverer.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You’ll be engaged to a woman, but another man will rape her. You’ll build a house, but you won’t live in it. You’ll plant a vineyard, but you won’t harvest it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Your ox will be slaughtered in front of you, and you won’t be able to eat it. Your donkey will be stolen from you while you watch and won’t be returned to you. Your flock of sheep will be handed to your enemies, and there will be no deliverer.
speaker: Narrator

text: Your sons and daughters will be given to another people while you watch. You won’t be able to approach them at all, and you’ll be powerless to help.
speaker: Narrator

text: “A people whom you don’t know will devour what your land and labor produces. You’ll be only oppressed and discouraged continuously
speaker: Narrator

text: until you are driven insane from what your eyes will see.
speaker: Narrator

text: “The Lord will afflict you with incurable boils on your knees and legs, and from the sole of your foot to the top of your head.
speaker: Narrator

text: “The Lord will banish you and your king whom you will appoint over you to go to a nation that neither you nor your ancestors have known, and there you’ll serve other gods of wood and stone.
speaker: Narrator

text: You’ll become a desolation and a proverb, and you’ll be mocked among the people where the Lord will drive you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “You’ll plant many seeds in a field, but your harvest will be small because the locust will consume it.
speaker: Narrator

text: You’ll plant a vineyard, but you won’t drink wine or harvest any grapes because worms will consume it.
speaker: Narrator

text: You’ll have olive trees throughout your territory, but you won’t be able to anoint yourself with oil because the olives will drop off the trees.
speaker: Narrator

text: You’ll bear sons and daughters, but they won’t belong to you because they’ll go into captivity.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whirling locusts will consume every tree and the produce of your land.
speaker: Narrator

text: The foreigner in your midst will be elevated higher and higher over you, while you are brought low little by little.
speaker: Narrator

text: He will lend to you, but you won’t lend to him. He’ll be the head, but you’ll be the tail.
speaker: Narrator

text: All these curses will come upon you and will overwhelm you until you are exterminated, because you didn’t obey the Lord your God to keep his commands and statutes, which he had commanded you.
speaker: Narrator

text: These curses will serve as a sign and wonder for you and your descendants as long as you live.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Because you didn’t serve the Lord your God joyfully and wholeheartedly, despite the abundance of everything you have,
speaker: Narrator

text: you’ll serve your enemies whom the Lord your God will send against you. You will serve in famine and in drought, in nakedness, and in lack of everything. They’ll set a yoke of iron upon your neck until they have exterminated you.
speaker: Narrator

text: “The Lord will raise a distant nation against you from the other side of the earth. Swooping down like a vulture,
speaker: Narrator

text: it will be a nation whose language you don’t understand, whose stern appearance neither shows regard nor extends grace to anyone whether old or young.
speaker: Narrator

text: Its army will consume the offspring of your animals and the produce of your soil until you are exterminated. They will leave you without your grain, wine, oil, the increase of your cattle, and the lamb of your flock, until you are completely destroyed.
speaker: Narrator

text: They’ll besiege all your cities until your high and fortified walls in which you have trusted collapse throughout the land. Indeed, they will besiege all your cities, which the Lord your God gave you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “You’ll eat your own children—the flesh of your sons and daughters, whom the Lord your God gave you—on account of the siege and the distress with which your enemy will oppress you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Even the compassionate man among you—the very sensitive one—will look with evil in his eyes toward his brother, his beloved wife, and his surviving sons, whom he spared.
speaker: Narrator

text: He will withhold from each of them the flesh of his sons that he is eating—since there will be nothing left—on account of the siege and distress with which your enemy will oppress you in all your cities.
speaker: Narrator

text: The most tender and sensitive lady among you, who doesn’t venture to touch the soles of her feet to the ground on account of her daintiness, will look with hostility in her eyes against her beloved husband, her sons, and her daughters.
speaker: Narrator

text: She will eat her afterbirth and her newborn children secretly—since there will be nothing left—on account of the siege and distress with which your enemy will oppress you in your cities.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “If you aren’t careful to observe all the words of this Law that have been written in this book, instructing you to fear this glorious and awesome name of the Lord your God,
speaker: Narrator

text: then he will inflict extraordinary plagues on you and your children, great and lasting plagues, and severe and lasting illnesses.
speaker: Narrator

text: He will inflict on you all the diseases of Egypt that you dreaded, and they won’t be curable.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moreover, the Lord will inflict you with illnesses and plagues that were not written in this Book of the Law, until you are exterminated.
speaker: Narrator

text: Because you will not have obeyed the Lord your God, very few of you will be left—instead of you being as numerous as the stars in the heavens.
speaker: Narrator

text: Just as the Lord delighted to prosper and increase you, so now the Lord will delight to destroy, exterminate, and banish you from the land that you are about to enter to possess.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “He’ll scatter you among the nations from one end of the earth to the other, and there you’ll serve other gods made of wood and stones, which neither you nor your ancestors have known.
speaker: Narrator

text: Among those nations you’ll have no rest. There’ll be no resting place for the soles of your feet. Instead, the Lord will give you an anxious heart, failing eyesight, and a despairing spirit.
speaker: Narrator

text: You’ll cling to life, being fearful by both night and day, with no assurance of survival.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the morning you’ll say, ‘I wish it were evening.’ Yet in the evening you’ll say, “I wish it were morning,” on account of what you’ll dread and what you’ll see.
speaker: Narrator

text: Finally, the Lord will bring you back to Egypt by ship, a place that I said you’ll never see again. There you’ll try to sell yourselves to your enemies as male and female slaves, but no one will buy you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the terms of the covenant that the Lord commanded Moses to make with the Israelis in the land of Moab in addition to the covenant that he made with them in Horeb.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses called all Israel together and addressed them: “You saw everything that the Lord did before your eyes in the land of Egypt to Pharaoh, to all his servants, and to his whole country.
speaker: Narrator

text: Those great feats that you saw with your own eyes are signs and great wonders.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yet to this day, the Lord hasn’t given you a heart that understands, eyes that perceive, and ears that discern.
speaker: Narrator

text: Though I’ve led you for 40 years in the desert, neither your clothes nor your shoes have worn out.
speaker: Narrator

text: You didn’t have bread to eat or wine or anything intoxicating to drink, so that you would learn that I am the Lord your God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then you reached this place, where King Sihon of Heshbon and King Og of Bashan had come out to meet and fight with us, but we defeated them.
speaker: Narrator

text: We captured their land and handed it as an inheritance to the descendants of Reuben, the descendants of Gad, and half the tribe of Manasseh.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, keep the terms of this covenant, carrying them out so that you’ll be wise in everything you do.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “All of you are standing today in the presence of the Lord your God—the heads of your tribes, your elders, your magistrates, all the men of Israel,
speaker: Narrator

text: along with your children, your wives, even the foreigner in your camp, including the woodchopper and the water drawer—
speaker: Narrator

text: to enter into a covenant with the Lord your God and into the oath that he is about to make with you today,
speaker: Narrator

text: so that he will elevate you to be a people for him. And he will be God to you, just as he promised you and swore to your ancestors Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now, I’m not making this covenant and oath with you alone,
speaker: Narrator

text: but with whoever is here with us standing in the presence of the Lord our God today, as well as with those who aren’t here with us today.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Now, you know how we lived in the land of Egypt and how we traveled through the territory of other nations.
speaker: Narrator

text: You have seen their detestable practices, their idols of wood, stone, silver, and gold that they had with them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Be alert so there is no man, woman, family, or tribe whose heart is turning away from the Lord your God to go and serve the gods of those nations. Be alert so there will be no root among you that produces poisonous and bitter fruit,
speaker: Narrator

text:
because when such a person hears the words of this oath, he will bless himself and say:
‘I will have a peaceful life, even though I’m determined to be stubborn.’ By doing this he will be sweeping away both watered and parched ground alike.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “The Lord won’t forgive such a person. Instead, the zealous anger of the Lord will blaze against him. All the curses that were written in this book will fall on him. Then the Lord will wipe out his memory from under heaven.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord will set him apart from all the tribes of Israel for destruction, according to the curses of the covenant that were written in this Book of the Law.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Then the generation to come—your descendants after you and the foreigners who come from afar—will see plagues and illnesses infecting the land that the Lord will inflict on it.
speaker: Narrator

text: The whole land will be covered with salt pits and burning sulfur, with nothing planted, nothing sprouting, and producing no vegetation—overthrown like Sodom, Gomorrah, Admah, and Zeboiim, when the Lord overthrew them in his raging fury.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the nations will ask, ‘Why did the Lord do this to this land? What is the meaning of this fierce and great anger?’
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then they will answer themselves,
‘Because they’ve abandoned the covenant of their Lord, the God of their ancestors that he had made with them when he brought them out of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: They followed and worshipped other gods whom they had not known and whom he did not assign to them.
speaker: Narrator

text: For this reason, the anger of the Lord raged against this land, to bring upon it all the curses that were written in this book.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord uprooted them from the land in his anger, wrath, and great fury, deporting them to another land, and that’s the way things are today.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “The secret things belong to the Lord our God, but what has been revealed belongs to us and to our children forever, so that we might observe the words of this Law.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “When all these things happen to you—both the blessings and the curses that I’ve presented to you—and you take them seriously in all the nations where the Lord your God will deport you,
speaker: Narrator

text: and when you—you and your descendants, that is—will have returned to him and obeyed all the commands that I’m giving you today with all your heart and soul,
speaker: Narrator

text: then the Lord your God will restore your fortunes and will show compassion to you. He will gather you from among the nations where he had scattered you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Even if the Lord had banished you to the ends of the heavens, the Lord your God will gather you from there
speaker: Narrator

text: and he’ll bring you to the land that your ancestors inherited. You’ll possess it, you’ll prosper, and you’ll greatly multiply more than your ancestors did.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord your God will circumcise both your hearts and those of your descendants so that you can love him with your heart and with your soul and therefore live.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord your God will inflict all these curses on your enemies and on those who hate and persecute you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “So now, return and obey the Lord your God and observe all his commands that I’m giving you today,
speaker: Narrator

text: and the Lord your God will prosper you abundantly in all that you do, along with your children, your livestock, and the produce of your fields, because the Lord your God will again be delighted with you for good, just as he was delighted with your ancestors,
speaker: Narrator

text: if you obey him and keep his commands and statutes that are written in this Book of the Law, and if you return to him with all your heart and soul.
speaker: Narrator

text: Indeed, these commands that I’m giving you today are neither confusing nor unattainable for you.
speaker: Narrator

text: They aren’t in the heavens, so you have to ask, ‘Who’ll go up to the heavens for us and get it for us so we can hear it and act on it?’
speaker: Narrator

text: And they aren’t beyond the seas either, so you have to ask, ‘Who’ll cross the sea and get it for us so we can hear it and act on it?’
speaker: Narrator

text: No, the word is very near you—it’s within your mouth and heart for you to attain.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Look! Today I have set before you life and what is good, along with death and what is evil.
speaker: Narrator

text: That’s why I’m commanding you today to love the Lord your God by walking in his ways and by observing his commands, statutes, and ordinances, so that you may live long, increase, and so that the Lord your God may bless you in the land that you are about to enter to possess.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if you turn your heart away, and do not obey, but instead if you stray away to worship and serve other gods,
speaker: Narrator

text: I’m declaring to you today that you will surely be destroyed. You won’t live long in the land that you are crossing the Jordan River to enter and possess.
speaker: Narrator

text: I call heaven and earth to testify against you today! I’ve set life and death before you today: both blessings and curses. Choose life, that it may be well with you—you and your children.
speaker: Narrator

text: Love the Lord your God, obey his voice, and cling to him, because he is your life—even your long life—so that you may live in the land that the Lord promised to give Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses went and explained these things to everyone in Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he concluded, “I’m now 120 years old. I’m not able to get around anymore,
speaker: Narrator

text: and the Lord told me, ‘You won’t be crossing the Jordan River.’ But the Lord your God is crossing over before you. He will destroy these nations in front of you and you will dispossess them. As for Joshua, he will cross over before you, just as the Lord promised.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord will do to them just as he did to Sihon and Og, the kings of the Amorites, and to their land when he destroyed them.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord will hand them over to you, so you can do to them what I’ve instructed you to do.
speaker: Narrator

text: Be strong and courageous. Don’t fear or tremble before them, because the Lord your God will be the one who keeps on walking with you—he won’t leave you or abandon you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses called on Joshua and told him in the presence of everyone in Israel, “Be strong and courageous, because you’ll bring this people to the land that the Lord your God had promised to give your ancestors. You will be the one who causes them to possess it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Indeed, the Lord is the one who will keep on walking in front of you. He’ll be with you and won’t leave you or abandon you, so never be afraid and never be dismayed.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses wrote down this Law and gave it to the Levitical priests who carry the Ark of the Covenant of the Lord and to all of Israel’s leaders.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he gave these orders: “At the end of seven years, the year designated for release, during the Festival of Tents,
speaker: Narrator

text: when all of Israel comes to appear in the presence of the Lord your God at the place that he’ll choose, read this Law aloud to them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Gather the people—the men, women, children, and the foreigners that live in your cities—so they may hear and fear the Lord your God, and so they may be careful to obey the words contained in this Law.
speaker: Narrator

text: Their children who don’t know will hear and learn to fear the Lord your God as long as you live in the land that you are crossing the Jordan River to possess.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord told Moses: “Look! Because your time to die is approaching, call Joshua, present yourselves at the Tent of Meeting, and then I will commission him.” Moses and Joshua complied and presented themselves at the Tent of Meeting.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Lord appeared at the tent in a pillar of cloud that stood above the entrance.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord told Moses, “Look! You are about to join your ancestors. Afterwards, this people will rebel and commit prostitution with the foreign gods of the land that they are about to enter to possess. They will abandon me and break my covenant that I made with them.
speaker: Narrator

text: When that happens, my anger will burn against them, because they will have abandoned me. I’ll hide my face from them, they will be consumed, and many evils and distresses will find them. When this happens, they will say, ‘These troubles have happened to us because God isn’t among us.’
speaker: Narrator

text: I’ll surely hide my face in that day on account of the evil that they will have done, because they will have turned to other gods.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Now write this song and teach it to the Israelis. Put this song in their very mouths, so that it will be a witness for me against the Israelis,
speaker: Narrator

text: because after I’ve brought them to the land flowing with milk and honey that I promised to their ancestors by an oath, they’ll eat, grow fat, and then they’ll turn to other gods and serve them, while despising me and breaking my covenant.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then, when many evils and troubles will have come upon them, this song will serve as a witness against them, since their descendants won’t fail to sing it. I know the plan that they are devising even before I bring them into the land that I promised them by an oath.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses wrote the song that very day and taught it to the Israelis.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord charged Nun’s son Joshua, “Be strong and courageous, because you’ll bring the Israelis to the land that I promised to them by an oath. I’ll be with you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Moses had finished writing the words of this Law in a book,
speaker: Narrator

text: he gave this charge to the descendants of Levi who carried the Ark of the Covenant of the Lord:
speaker: Narrator

text: “Take the book of this Law and set it beside the Ark of the Covenant of the Lord your God. Let it remain there with you as a witness against you,
speaker: Narrator

text: because indeed I know your rebellion and stubbornness. Note that even while I’m still alive, you’ve been rebelling against the Lord—how much more so after my death!
speaker: Narrator

text: Gather together the leaders of your tribes and your foremen so I can speak these words in their hearing and call heaven and the earth as witnesses against them,
speaker: Narrator

text: because I know that after my death, you’ll surely act wickedly and turn from the road that I’ve instructed you. As a result, evil will fall on you in days to come, because you’ll act wickedly in the sight of the Lord, causing him to become angry due to your behavior.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses spoke the words of this song—to the very end—in front of the entire assembly of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Hear, heavens, and I will speak!
    Listen, earth, to the words of my mouth!
speaker: Narrator

text:
May my instructions descend like rain
    and may my words flow like dew,
as light rain upon the grass,
    and as showers upon new plants.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For I’ll proclaim the name of our Lord.
    Ascribe greatness to our God!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Flawless is the work of the Rock,
    because all his ways are just.
A faithful God—never unjust—
    righteous and upright is he.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
This is not the way to repay the Lord, is it,
    you foolish and witless people?
Is he not your father,
    who bought you, formed you, and established you?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Remember the days of old,
    reflect on the years of previous generations.
Ask your father,
    and he’ll tell you;
        your elders will inform you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When the Most High gave nations as their inheritance,
    when he separated the human race,
he set boundaries for the people
    according to the number of the children of God.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For the Lord’s portion is his people;
    Jacob is his allotted portion.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord found him in a desert land,
    in a barren, eerie wilderness.
He surrounded, cared for, and guarded him
    as the pupil of his eye.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Like an eagle stirs its nest,
    hovering near its young,
spreading out his wings to take him
    and carry him on his pinions,
speaker: Narrator

text:
the Lord alone guided him.
    There was no foreign god with him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He mounted him on a high place above the earth,
    feeding him from the produce of the field.
He nourished him with honey from the rock
    and with oil from the flint rock,
speaker: Narrator

text:
with curds from cattle and with milk from sheep,
    with the fat of lambs, with rams from Bashan,
with the fat of goats, with the finest of wheat—
    and from the juice of grapes you drank wine.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Jacob dined until satisfied;
    Jeshurun grew fat and kicked.
He grew fat, coarse, and gross,
    so that he abandoned the God who made him
        and spurned the Rock that was his salvation.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They provoked him to jealousy over foreigners
    and to anger over detestable things.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They sacrificed to demons—
    not to the real God—
gods whom they didn’t know,
    new neighbors who had recently appeared,
        whom your ancestors never feared.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You neglected the Rock that fathered you;
    you abandoned God, who was awaiting your birth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord saw it and became jealous,
    provoked by his sons and daughters.
speaker: Narrator

text:
So he said: 
“Let me hide my face from them.
    I will observe what their end will be,
because they are a perverted generation,
    children within whom there is no loyalty.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They provoked me to jealousy over non-gods,
    and to be angry over their vanity.
Now I’ll provoke them to jealousy over a non-people;
    and over a foolish nation I’ll provoke them to anger.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For a fire breaks out in my anger—
    burning to the deepest part of the afterlife,
consuming the earth and its produce
    and igniting the foundations of the mountains.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I’ll bury them in misfortunes
    and bring them to an end with my arrows.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Emaciated from famine,
    feverish from plague,
    and destroyed by bitterness,
I’ll send fanged beasts against them,
    along with poisonous snakes that glide through the dust.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
“I said, 
‘I will scatter them,
    erasing their memory from the human race,
speaker: Narrator

text:
if it weren’t for dreading the taunting of their enemies—
    otherwise, their adversary might misinterpret and say,
“Our power is great.
    It isn’t the Lord who made all of this happen.”’”
speaker: Narrator

text:
They are a nation devoid of purpose
    and without insight.
speaker: Narrator

text:
O, that they were wise to understand this
    and consider their future!
speaker: Narrator

text:
How can one person chase a thousand of them
    and two put a myriad to flight,
unless their Rock delivers them
    and the Lord gives them up?
speaker: Narrator

text:
For their rock isn’t like our Rock,
    as even our enemies admit.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Instead, their vine is from the vines of Sodom
    and the vineyards of Gomorrah.
Their grapes are poisonous,
    their clusters bitter.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Their wine is the venom of serpents,
    a poisonous cobra.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Is this not kept in reserve,
    sealed up with me in my treasury?
speaker: Narrator

text:
To me belong vengeance and recompense.
    In due time their feet will slip,
because their time of calamity is near
    and the things prepared for them draw near.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For the Lord will vindicate his people
    and bring comfort to his servants,
because he will observe that their power has waned,
    when neither prisoner nor free person remain.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“He will say, ‘Where are their gods,
    the rock in which they took refuge?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who ate the fat of their offerings
    and drank the wine that was their drink offering?
Let them rise and help you
    and be your hiding place!’
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Look now! I AM,
    and there is no other god besides me.
I myself cause death
    and I sustain life;
I wound severely
    and I also heal;
        from my power no one can deliver.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“I solemnly swear to heaven—
    I say ‘As certainly as I’m alive and living forever,
speaker: Narrator

text:
I’ll whet my shining sword,
    with my hands in firm grasp of judgment.
I’ll show vengeance on my adversary
    and repay those who keep on hating me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I’ll make my arrows drunk with blood.
    My sword will devour flesh,
        along with the blood of the slain,
    and I’ll take their enemy leaders captive.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Sing for joy, nations!
    Sing for joy, people who belong to him!
For he’ll avenge the blood of his servants,
    turn on his adversary,
        and cleanse both his land and his people.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses and Nun’s son Joshua came and recited all the words of this song while the people were assembled.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Moses had finished addressing all of these words to all Israel,
speaker: Narrator

text: he told them, “Take to heart my entire testimony against you today. Command your children to observe carefully every word of this Law,
speaker: Narrator

text: because they’re not just empty words for you—they are your very life. Through these instructions you will live long in the land that you are about to cross over the Jordan River to possess.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Later that day, the Lord told Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Ascend this Abarim mountain range toward Mount Nebo in the land of Moab across from Jericho, and look out over the land of Canaan that I’m about to give to the Israelis as a possession.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will die on the mountain that you are about to ascend and be taken to be with your ancestors, just as your brother Aaron died on Mount Hor and was taken to be with his ancestors.
speaker: Narrator

text: Both of you acted unfaithfully against me among the Israelis at Meribah-kadesh in the desert of Zin, when you failed to uphold my holiness among the Israelis.
speaker: Narrator

text: You’ll see the land from a distance, but you won’t be able to enter the land that I am about to give to the Israelis.”
speaker: Narrator

text: This is the blessing with which Moses, the man of God, blessed the Israelis before his death.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He said:
“The Lord came from Sinai.
    Rising from Seir upon us,
he shone forth from Mount Paran,
    accompanied by a myriad of his holy ones,
        with flaming fire from his right hand for them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Indeed, lover of people,
    all of his holy ones are in your control.
They gather at your feet
    to do as you have instructed.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Moses commanded with the Law,
    an inheritance for the community of Jacob.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord was king of Jeshurun
    when the leaders of the people—
        all the tribes of Israel—gathered together.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“May Reuben live and not die,
    though his numbers are few.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
He declared this about Judah:
“Hear, Lord, the voice of Judah
    and return him to his people.
With his own strength he fights for himself,
    and you will be of assistance against his enemies.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
About Levi he said:
“Let your Thummim and Urim be with the man
    to whom you showed gracious love,
whom you tested at Massah
    and with whom you struggled
        at the waters of Meribah,
speaker: Narrator

text:
the one who told his mother and father,
    ‘I don’t know them,’
and who would neither acknowledge his brothers
    nor know his own children.
For they kept your word
    and guarded your covenant.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They will teach your ordinances to Jacob,
    and your Law to Israel.
They will offer incense as a pleasant aroma to you
    and a whole burnt offering upon your altar.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Lord, bless his substance
    and approve the work that he undertakes.
Shatter the legs of those who oppose against him;
    may those who hate him stand no more.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
About Benjamin he said:
“The beloved of the Lord will live confidently,
    the Most High protecting him all day long,
        and resting in his bosom.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
About Joseph he said:
“May the blessing of the Lord be on his land:
    dew from the choicest of the heavens,
        and from the depths beneath;
speaker: Narrator

text:
from the choicest products of the sun,
    the rich fruit of the harvest moon,
speaker: Narrator

text:
the choicest portion of the eternal mountains,
    and the best of the everlasting hills;
speaker: Narrator

text:
from the choicest of the earth and its fullness,
    and the favor of the one who lived in the burning bush.
May blessing rest on Joseph’s head,
    and on the crown of the head
        of the one set apart from his brothers.
speaker: Narrator

text:
May the firstborn of his bull be honorable to him,
    and may his horns be those of a wild ox.
With them may he push people all together,
    to the ends of the earth.
These are the myriads of Ephraim
    and the thousands of Manasseh.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
About Zebulun he said:
“Zebulun, rejoice as you go out
    and Issachar, in being inside your tents.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They will call the nations to the mountain,
    and there they will offer righteous sacrifices,
for they’ll draw from the abundance of the sea
    and from the hidden treasures of the sand.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
About Gad he said:
“Blessed be the one who enlarges Gad!
    Like a roaring lion, he crouches,
        tearing arm and scalp.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He chose the best part for himself,
    when the leader’s portion was assigned.
He came at the head of the people,
    carrying out the Lord’s justice
        and his ordinances concerning Israel.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
About Dan he said:
“Dan is a lion’s cub,
    leaping forth from Bashan.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
About Naphtali he said:
“Naphtali, full of favor and the Lord’s blessing,
    take possession of the west and south.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
About Asher he said:
“May Asher be blessed, along with his descendants,
    may his brothers be pleased with him,
        may he dip his feet in oil,
speaker: Narrator

text:
may your bolts be made of iron and bronze,
    and may your strength be sufficient for each day you live.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“There is no one like the God of Jeshurun,
    who rides through the heavens
        with its lofty clouds to help you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The God of old is a dwelling place,
    with everlasting arms underneath.
He drove out your enemies before you
    and said: ‘Destroy them!’
speaker: Narrator

text:
So Israel lives in confidence,
    isolated as the fountain of Jacob
in a land of grain and new wine,
    where the heavens rain down dew.
speaker: Narrator

text:
How blessed are you, Israel!
    Who can be like you,
a people delivered by the Lord,
    your shield of help and
        your finely crafted sword.
May your enemies cower before you.
    You will tread down their high places.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses ascended from the desert plain of Moab toward Mount Nebo, to the top of Pisgah, across from Jericho. There the Lord showed him the entire land, from Gilgal as far as Dan,
speaker: Narrator

text: all of Naphtali, the territories of Ephraim and Manasseh, and the entire territory of Judah all the way to out over the sea,
speaker: Narrator

text: including the Negev, the Arabah, the valley of Jericho, and the city of the palm trees as far as Zoar.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord told him: “This is the land that I promised to Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob by an oath when I said, ‘I’ll give it to your descendants.’ I’ll let you see it with your eyes, but you won’t cross over there.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses, the servant of the Lord, died there in the land of Moab, just as the Lord had said.
speaker: Narrator

text: He was buried in the valley opposite Beth Peor, in the land of Moab, but no one knows to this day where his burial place is.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses was 120 years old when he died. His eyesight wasn’t impaired and he was still vigorous and strong.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Israelis mourned for Moses at the desert plain of Moab for 30 days, after which the period of mourning for Moses was completed.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Nun’s son Joshua was full of the spirit of wisdom, because Moses had placed his hands on him, so the Israelis listened to him and did what the Lord had commanded Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: No prophet ever rose again in Israel like Moses, whom the Lord knew with such great intimacy.
speaker: Narrator

text: What signs and wonders the Lord sent him to do throughout the land of Egypt, to Pharaoh, and to all of his servants who lived in the whole land!
speaker: Narrator

text: What great power and great terror Moses displayed on behalf of all Israel!
speaker: Narrator
